    No certificate of inspection shall be issued unless all installations are in strict conformity with the provisions of this article, the National Electrical Code and the statutes of the state and unless they are in conformity with the most approved methods of construction for safety to life and property. 
(Code 1965, § 10-5) 
Sec. 5-31. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who shall be convicted of violation of any of the provisions of the electrical code, or failure to comply therewith, or of violation or failure to comply with any order made hereunder, or of making any installation in violation or any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder and from which no appeal has been taken, or of failure to comply with such an order, as affirmed or modified by the Louisiana Rating and Fire Prevention Bureau or by a court of compensation jurisdiction, or of violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall for each and every violation and noncompliance be punished as provided by section 1-8. 
(b)  The imposition of one penalty for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to continue, and all violators shall be required to correct or remedy such violations or defects within a reasonable time. When not otherwise specified, each ten (10) days that prohibited conditions are maintained shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  The application of any of the above penalties shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Code 1965, § 10-2) 
Secs. 5-32-5-39. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICIANS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate electricians, R.S. 33:4782. 

Sec. 5-40. - Board; created, membership. 
    There is created an electrical board for the city, which board is to consist of the city electrical inspector and five (5) other members to be appointed each year by the mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the governing body. 
(Code 1965, § 10-43) 
Sec. 5-41. - Application for certificate and examination. 
    Any person desiring a journeyman electrician's, master electrician's or electrical contractor's certificate of competency shall make application in writing to the city electrical inspector, requesting that such applicant be permitted to take an examination for such certificate of competency. 
(Code 1965, § 10-44) 
Sec. 5-42. - Fees-Application. 
    The following fees shall be charged each applicant for examination or registration, or both, and shall be paid at the time the application is filed: 
(1)  Master electrician or electrical contractor ..... $50.00 
(2)  Journeyman electrician ..... 25.00 
(Code 1965, § 10-45; Ord. No. 1185, § 4, 6-11-96) 
Sec. 5-43. - Same-Expiration of certificates; renewal. 
    All certificates of competency shall expire on December thirty-first of each year and must be renewed on or before March first of the following year and the following fees shall be charged each applicant for renewal of his certificate of competency: 
(1)  Master electrician or electrical contractor ..... $50.00 
(2)  Journeyman electrician ..... 25.00 
(Code 1965, § 10-50; Ord. No. 1185, § 5, 6-11-96) 
Sec. 5-44. - Effect of not performing work during previous twelve months. 
    In the event that the applicant for renewal has not performed electrical work in the city during the previous twelve (12) month period, the application for registration shall be considered a new application for examination and registration and the fees hereinabove shown shall apply, except in cases of hardship or unusual circumstances, in which event the electrical board may consider the application a renewal application. 
(Code 1965, § 10-46) 
Sec. 5-45. - Examination of masters and contractors. 
    If the board shall find, upon due investigation, that the applicant for a master electrician's certificate of competency or an electrical contractor's certificate of competency is at least twenty-one (21) years of age and has had at least four (4) years' practical experience as a journeyman electrician, or is a graduate of any technical school of recognized standing and, in addition thereto, has had two (2) years of practical experience as a journeyman electrician and is of a good moral character, applicant shall be given the examination. The examination shall be given to the applicant within thirty (30) days after filing of the application, or as soon thereafter as possible; examination papers shall be graded by the board. The applicant shall satisfy such board that such person is a master of such person's trade or calling. 
(Code 1965, § 10-48) 
Sec. 5-46. - Examination of journeymen. 
    If the board shall find, after due examination, that the applicant for a journeyman electrician's certificate of competency is at least twenty-one (21) year of age and has had at least four (4) years' practical experience as an electrician's helper or as a journeyman electrician or is a graduate of any technical school of recognized standing and, in addition thereto, has had one (1) year of practical experience as an electrician's helper or as a journeyman electrician and is of good moral character, applicant shall be given the examination. The examination shall be given the applicant within thirty (30) days after the filing of the application or as soon thereafter as possible; examination papers shall be graded by the board. The applicant shall satisfy the board that such applicant is sufficiently proficient in applicant's trade or calling to qualify as a journeyman electrician. 
(Code 1965, § 10-49) 
Sec. 5-47. - Revocation of certificates. 
    Any certificate granted under this division may be revoked by the board should the licensee fail to comply with the provisions of this article and the National Electrical Code. 
(Code 1965, § 10-51) 
Sec. 5-48. - Bond insurance and licenses. 
    Every person, before entering into the business of installing or contracting to install or repair electrical wiring, electrical devices, equipment, signs and other electrical installations operating on a difference of potential of ten (10) volts or more, shall: 
(1)  Obtain the necessary certificates hereinabove required; 
(2)  Obtain and deposit with the electrical inspector an electrical contractor's bond in the principal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), executed by a solvent surety company, which bond shall be conditioned that the principal therein shall faithfully comply with the terms of this article and the National Electrical Code and shall indemnify and hold harmless the city and all persons interested against all costs, expenses, damage and injuries sustained by the negligence of such principal, principal's agents, servants and employees, failure to comply with the terms of this article and the code in doing work made the subject matter hereof and, otherwise, to be in the form and executed as required by the governing authority. This bond shall be renewed annually before the first day of January, as a prerequisite to the issuance of an electrical contractor's license for that year; and post a policy of adequate insurance; and 
(3)  Obtain from the city clerk all necessary occupational licenses to engage in the business. 
(Code 1965, § 10-53) 
Sec. 5-49. - Established place of business required; display of licenses. 
    Every licensed master electrician shall have and maintain an established place of business in the state displaying a sign in public view and, during regular business hours, shall have a responsible person in attendance at such place of business to receive complaints from the electrical department of the city, or other persons concerned, and must display, in said establishment, all necessary cite and state license tax receipts required by law. 
(Code 1965, § 10-54) 
Sec. 5-50. - Responsibility of electricians. 
    Every person certified by the board and licensed under this article shall be responsible for any defects in construction, insofar as correction thereof is concerned, in all work installed by such person, until such time as a certificate of approval has been issued by the electrical inspector, and shall also be so responsible for all defects that may have been concealed by such licensee and discovered by the electrical inspector, or the inspector's duly authorized agent, after a certificate of approval has been issued by such inspector, approving such construction. After the issuance of the certificate of approval, the person in whose name the meter is contracted shall be responsible for all defects caused by such person. 
(Code 1965, § 10-55) 
Secs. 5-51-5-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONDITION OF PROPERTY, BUILDINGS AND STRUCTURES[4] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. 1378, adopted Jan. 8, 2008, amended art. III, which pertained to housing, consisted of §§ 5-60-5-62, and derived from the 1965 Code, in its entirety to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 5-60. - Dilapidated dangerous structures and unsanitary conditions prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any property owner to allow any unsanitary or unsafe condition or any dilapidated or dangerous building or structure to exist on any lot, place or area owned by such property owner within the corporate limits of the City of Crowley. 
(Ord. No. 1378, § 2, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 5-61. - Condemnation of buildings and structures, adoption of state statutes. 
    The provisions of Subpart D of Chapter 14 of Title 33, particularly LA R.S. 33:4761, et seq., are hereby adopted as amended providing authority and the procedures for the condemnation, demolition and removal of buildings within the municipality as same may be amended by Legislature from time-to-time. The procedures provided therein shall be conformed to by the City of Crowley. 
(Ord. No. 1378, § 3, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 5-62. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions hereof shall be enforced by the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 1378, § 4, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 5-63. - Maintenance of property, buildings and structures. 
    All properties, buildings and structures, both existing and new, and all parts thereof, shall be maintained in a safe and sanitary condition fit for human habitation or the use for which [it] was intended. All devices, electrical, wiring, plumbing, plumbing fixtures, material, equipment and safeguards required in a building or structure when erected, altered or repaired shall be maintained in good condition and working order. 
(Ord. No. 1378, § 5, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 5-64. - Unsafe or dilapidated buildings. 
    All exterior walls, roofs or foundations shall be free from holes, breaks, loose or rotting boards or timber or any other condition which may admit rain or dampness into the interior which may cause damage to the building or structure. 
(Ord. No. 1378, § 6, 1-8-08) 
Sec. 5-65. - Unsafe, unsanitary or dilapidated buildings or structures. 
(a)  A lot, building or structure shall be deemed unsafe, unsanitary or dilapidated and unfit for human habitation, uninhabitable or unusable by reason of partial or complete damage or destruction, decay, deterioration, faulty construction, movement or instability of any portion of the structure, support or foundation. 
(b)  A lot, building or structure shall be deemed uninhabitable and unfit for human habitation because of decay, damage, faulty construction, inadequate light, ventilation, plumbing or sanitary facilities, inoperable or otherwise determined by the building inspector to be obsolete, not substantially impaired or otherwise not in accordance with the code requirements. 
(c)  Whenever a lot, building or structure, or a portion thereof, is left open and is unsecured and has not been secured by either placing boards or other material over doors, windows or other points of entry in such a manner [as] to maintain its present condition, to prevent further damage, decay or injury to the public, or when such place becomes an attractive nuisance to children or allows access to permit unlawful acts to occur, said building shall be deemed unsafe and dilapidated. 
(d)  Buildings destroyed or partially destroyed or damaged by natural or other occurrences, acts of God, force majeure, fire or catastrophe and which have remained in such state for more than ninety (90) days shall be deemed unsafe and/or dilapidated. 
(e)  All such lots, buildings and structures are hereby declared to be public nuisances and a danger to public health, safety and welfare and shall be condemned, demolished and/or removed unless repaired or rehabilitated and all corrections made to restore said lot, building or structure to conditions as may be required by the fire marshal and/or building inspector. 
(f)  Buildings or structures and/or any portion, appurtenance, ornamentation or accessory thereof, which has been declared a fire hazard due to deterioration, decay, damage, faulty wiring, gas connections or other equipment shall be deemed unsafe and/or dilapidated. 
(Ord. No. 1378, § 7, 1-8-08) 
Secs. 5-66-5-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PLUMBING AND GAS FITTING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-70. - Scope. 
    This article shall apply to and include all plumbing work and gas work, installation or equipment installed, constructed or altered in or about a building or structure of any kind, class or character, or to be used for any purpose whatsoever. Where appropriate, the provisions hereof shall be understood to refer also to gas fitters and gas fitting. 
(Code 1965, § 18-1) 
Sec. 5-71. - Plumbing inspector-General duties. 
    The plumbing inspector shall have the duty: 
(1)  To issue all permits for plumbing work; and 
(2)  To inspect and pass upon all plumbing and inspect any plumbing of any character already in use or being constructed which such inspector may have reason to believe is out of repair or imperfect. 
(Code 1965, § 18-3) 
Sec. 5-72. - Same-Authority to stop construction or use of improper plumbing, additional fee. 
(a)  The plumbing inspector shall have the authority, by written order to the owner or agent in charge of any building or premises where any imperfect or out of repair plumbing may be located, or to the plumber in charge of the construction of same, to stop the further construction or use of such plumbing until it has been properly constructed or repaired. 
(b)  The owner, agent or plumber in charge of the construction ordered to cease further construction until such hazard has been corrected shall pay an additional inspection fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Code 1965, § 18-4; Ord. No. 1185, § 6, 6-11-96) 
Sec. 5-73. - Same-Right-of-entry. 
    The plumbing inspector shall have the power to enter any premises in the city at any time between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. for the purposes of making any inspection or performing such inspector's powers or duties under this article. 
(Code 1965, § 18-5) 
Sec. 5-74. - Certification of plumbers-Required; board of examiners; procedure. 
(a)  The governing authority shall appoint a board of examiners of plumbers, consisting of the plumbing inspector and five (5) other members who shall serve for a term of one year and who shall meet, organize and adopt rules to carry into effect the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Said board shall give examinations to all applicants for plumbing certificates of competency, provided that no applicant for such examination shall be given an examination unless and until such applicant has had not less than three (3) years' experience as a plumber's apprentice, working under the supervision of a qualified master plumber and holds a certificate issued by the state board of examiners of journeyman plumbers. 
(c)  The board shall designate the time of meetings for the examination of applicants for such certificates or to hear and determine any appeals from the rulings of the inspector or any charges that may be made against any master plumber or any journeyman plumber or for the transaction of any other business. 
(d)  Any person holding an unrevoked and current journeyman plumber's, master plumber's or plumbing contractor's certificate of competency or a license as such from any municipality of the state classified, under the laws of the state, as a city, and a certificate issued by the state plumbing board shall be issued a like certificate of competency of the city, without examination, upon payment of the fees hereinafter shown and the presentation to the plumbing inspector of satisfactory evidence that the applicant holds such certificate or license. 
(e)  All applications shall be in writing in the form required by the plumbing inspector. 
(f)  The following fees shall be charged each applicant for the examination or registration, or both, and shall be paid at the time the application is filed: 
(1)  Master plumber or plumbing contractor ..... $50.00 
(2)  Journeyman plumber ..... 25.00 
(g)  All certificates of competency shall expire on December thirty-first of each year and must be renewed on or before March first of the following year and the following fees shall be charged each applicant for renewal of the certificate of competency: 
(1)  Master plumber or plumbing contractor ..... $50.00 
(2)  Journeyman plumber ..... 25.00 
(h)  In the event that the applicant for renewal has not performed plumbing work in the city during the previous twelve (12) month period, such applicant's application for registration shall be considered a new application for examination and registration and the fees firstly hereinabove shown shall apply, except in cases of hardship or unusual circumstances; in which event, the board of examiners of plumbers may consider the application a renewal application. 
(i)  All journeyman plumbers, master plumbers and plumbing contractors now licensed under the ordinances of the city may apply for and obtain, without examination, certificates of competence for the current year by payment of the renewal fees hereinabove set out. 
(j)  After hearing before the board, any such certificates may be revoked by the board should the licensee fail to comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 18-16; Ord. No. 1185, § 7, 6-11-96) 
Sec. 5-75. - Same-Bond and license. 
    Every person, before entering into the business of installing or contracting to install or repair plumbing or house drains or both, in connection with the sewage system of the city, shall: 
(1)  Obtain the necessary certificates hereinabove required; 
(2)  Obtain and deposit with the plumbing inspector a plumbing contractor's bond in the principal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), executed by a solvent surety company, which bond shall be conditioned that the principal therein shall faithfully comply with the terms of this article and shall indemnify and hold harmless the city and all persons interested against all costs, expenses, damage and injuries sustained by the negligence of such principal, applicant's agents, servants and employees, or failure to comply with the terms of this article in doing work made the subject matter hereof or any other plumbing work and, otherwise, to be in the form and executed as required by the governing authority. Such bond shall be renewed annually before the first day of January, as a prerequisite to the issuance of a plumbing contractor's license for that year; and 
(3)  Obtain from the city clerk all necessary occupational licenses to engage in the business. 
(Code 1965, § 18-17) 
Sec. 5-76. - Plumber responsible for work. 
    The master plumber in charge of the work shall be responsible for the construction and completion, according to this article, of all interior drainage and all supply pipes within the buildings, and their proper connections to the main house drain leading to the public sewer and connection to sewer. 
(Code 1965, § 18-18) 
Sec. 5-77. - Plumbing permits and plans-Required; application; performance of plumbing work. 
(a)  No property owner shall connect to or cause or permit any connection with a city sewer, house sewer or the water supply servicing the city, or erect or install or permit the erection or installation of any plumbing or fixtures to be connected therewith until such property owner or the licensed plumber who is to perform the work has obtained from the plumbing inspector a permit therefor. Application for such permit shall be made on the form prescribed, stating the location of the property, with a full and clear description of the work proposed, signed by such property owner or the licensed plumber and agreeing that applicant will conform with the rules and ordinances regulating sewer connections and plumbing. Each 
application shall be accompanied by a diagram and specifications made in duplicate on the form prescribed and furnished by the inspector, showing and describing clearly the location of the building and of the rooms containing the work, the connections with the sewer and water supply, with every pipe, fixture and connection, neatly drawn in ink. If one vertical section cannot be made to show the work fully, other drawings are to be added. In showing extensions, the old work is to be shown in red ink and all new work in black ink. 
(b)  No permit hereunder shall be issued except to the owner of the property on which the work is to be performed or a qualified and licensed plumber. 
(c)  A person who is not a licensed plumber may perform plumbing as defined in Louisiana Revised Statutes, section 37:1377(d) as now enacted or hereafter amended and connections to the house sewer or the city system and to the water supply servicing the city only in accordance with the provisions and exceptions contained in Louisiana Revised Statutes, sections 37:1361 through 37:1379 as now enacted or hereafter amended and only after a permit has been issued for such work when such permit is required by this article. 
(Code 1965, § 18-6) 
Sec. 5-78. - Same-When permit not required. 
    No permit will be required for minor work such as repair of leaks in pipes, traps, drains or faucets or opening up waste or supply pipes or replacing broken fixtures. 
(Code 1965, § 18-6) 
Sec. 5-79. - Same-Approval of plans, issuance of permit. 
    If the application and plans are approved by the inspector, such inspector shall issue a written permit within twenty-four (24) hours after the application is filed. 
(Code 1965, § 18-8) 
Sec. 5-80. - Same-Changes in plans. 
    Approved plans may not be changed unless the change is submitted and approved in the same manner as the original plans. 
(Code 1965, § 18-9) 
Sec. 5-81. - Same-Using same plans for identical systems. 
    The same plans may serve for each of several buildings located together and having identical plumbing systems. 
(Code 1965, § 18-10) 
Sec. 5-82. - Same-Lapse of permits. 
    Each permit shall lapse and become void if the work is not completed within ninety (90) days from the date of the permit, unless a longer period is expressly allowed by the inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 18-11) 
Sec. 5-83. - Same-Fees. 
(a)  The following permit and inspection fees shall be paid at the time a permit is issued: 
(1)  First fixture ..... $10.00 
(2)  Each additional fixture ..... 3.00 
(b)  The term "fixture" shall include, but is not limited to, the following: water closets, catch basins, mud traps, slop sinks, bathtubs, kitchen sinks, urinals, wash trays, wash basins, pantry sinks, drinking fountains, showers, floor drains, fountains and any other type of plumbing fixture. Each waste opening or piping which terminates for future connections shall be considered a fixture. 
(c)  Where more than one inspection is required for any reason, the inspector shall charge and collect an additional fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) [that] shall be charged for each additional inspection required and shall be paid prior to each additional inspection. 
(d)  The following sewer tap permit and inspection fees shall be paid at the time a permit is issued: 
(1)  Sewer tap/no street break: $200.00. 
(2)  Sewer tap/break or cut street of less than one-half width of street: $450.00, plus an additional $100.00 for concrete street. 
(3)  Sewer tap/break or cut street of more than one-half width of street: $800.00, plus an additional $100.00 for concrete street. 
(Code 1965, § 18-12; Ord. No. 1185, § 8, 6-11-96; Ord. 1432, § 3, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 5-84. - Plumbing inspections and tests-Required; procedure. 
    All sewer lines shall be inspected when the pipe has been laid and cemented and before it is covered. As soon as all soil pipes, waste pipes, vent pipes and traps are connected, they shall be tested by the plumber in the presence of the inspector by filling them entirely with water. If any leaks appear, they are to be stopped by removal of the broken or defective pieces, caulking the lead or tightening screw threads but not by use of plumbers cement. The entire height of the pipe system is to be tested at once, unless the building is over three (3) stories in height, in which event the work may be tested in sections, provided no section may be less than three (3) stories in height. In addition to the water test, an approved smoke test or pressure test may be required in the presence of the inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 18-13) 
Sec. 5-85. - Same-Covering unapproved work prohibited. 
    All work must be left uncovered and convenient for examination until inspected and approved. 
(Code 1965, § 18-14) 
Sec. 5-86. - Same-Furnishing water to, using unapproved plumbing. 
    No water shall be turned on, except for inspection, and no plumbing fixtures shall be used, until the inspector has issued a certificate of final inspection and approval. 
(Code 1965, § 18-15) 
Sec. 5-87. - Gas inspection permit. 
(a)  For the issuance of an inspection permit, the inspector shall charge and collect a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(b)  Where more than one inspection is required for any reason, the inspector shall charge and collect an additional fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each additional inspection. 
(Code 1965, § 13-10; Ord. No. 1185, § 8, 6-11-96; Ord. 1432, § 4, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 5-88. - Gas certificate required before turning gas on. 
    The inspector shall furnish to the gas supplier a copy of each certificate of inspection. It shall be unlawful for the gas supplier to turn gas into any new or altered or repaired system of gas piping until such certificate has been received, but when the inspector has certified to the inspection herein provided, no further inspection by the gas supplier shall be required. 
(Code 1965, § 13-11) 
Sec. 5-89. - Discontinuing gas service to defective installations. 
    Every person learning of a leak or defect in any gas piping or appliance shall forthwith report all facts in connection therewith in writing to the inspector. The inspector shall thereupon inspect all gas equipment at the location named in such report, and if such inspector finds leaks or defects, such inspector may order the gas company to turn off the gas and it shall be unlawful thereafter for the gas company to turn the gas on again until the inspector has certified that such leak has been repaired or removed. 
(Code 1965, § 13-12) 
Sec. 5-90. - Tampering with gas supplier facilities. 
    No one, except the gas supplier owning or supplying gas through the service line, shall at any time turn any valve or cock or in way tamper or make any connection with any gas main, meter, meter connection or gas service pipe between the main and meter. 
(Code 1965, § 13-13) 
Secs. 5-91-5-99. - Reserved.
