(a)  It shall be a misdemeanor for a person to knowingly or intentionally, in a sexually oriented business, appear in a state of nudity or engage in specified sexual activities. 
(b)  It shall be a misdemeanor for a person to knowingly or intentionally, in a sexually oriented business, appear in a seminude condition, unless the person is an employee who, while seminude, is at least six (6) feet from any patron or customer and on a stage at least two (2) feet from the floor. 
(c)  It shall be a misdemeanor for an employee, while seminude in a sexually oriented business, to receive directly any pay or gratuity from any patron or customer, or for any patron or customer to pay or give any gratuity directly to an employee, while that employee is seminude in a sexually oriented business. 
(d)  It shall be a misdemeanor for an employee, while seminude, to knowingly and intentionally touch a customer or the clothing of a customer. 
(Ord. No. 1264, § 6-216, 1-14-03) 
Sec. 11-176. - Prohibition against children in a sexually oriented business. 
    A person commits a misdemeanor if the person knowingly allows a person under the age of eighteen (18) years on the premises of a sexually oriented business. 
(Ord. No. 1264, § 6-217, 1-14-03) 
Sec. 11-177. - Hours of operation. 
    No sexually oriented business, except for an adult motel, may remain open at any time between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on weekdays and Saturdays, and 1:00 a.m. and 12:00 p.m. on Sundays. 
(Ord. No. 1264, § 6-218, 1-14-03) 
Sec. 11-178. - Exemptions. 
    It is a defense to prosecution under section 11-175 that a person appearing in a state of nudity did so in a modeling class operated: 
(a)  By a proprietary school, licensed by the State of Louisiana; a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; or 
(b)  By a private college or university which maintains and operates educational programs in which credits are transferable to a college, junior college, or university supported entirely or partly by taxation; or 
(c)  In a structure: 
(1)  Which has no sign visible from the exterior of the structure and no other advertising that indicates a nude person is available for viewing; and 
(2)  Where, in order to participate in a class, a student must enroll at least three (3) days in advance of the class; and 
(3)  Where no more than one nude model is on the premises at any one time. 
(Ord. No. 1264, § 6-219, 1-14-03) 
Sec. 11-179. - Injunction. 
    A person who operates or causes to be operated a sexually oriented business without a valid license or in violation of section 111-171 of this article is subject to a suit for injunction as well as prosecution for criminal violations. Such violations shall be punishable by a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) or thirty (30) days imprisonment. Each day a sexually oriented business so operates is a separate offense or violation. 
(Ord. No. 1264, § 6-220, 1-14-03) 
Sec. 11-180. - Severability. 
    Each section and provision of this article are hereby declared to be independent divisions and subdivisions and, not withstanding any other evidence of legislative intent, it is hereby declared to be the controlling legislative intent that if any provisions of said article, or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held to be invalid, the remaining sections or provisions and the application of such sections and provisions to any person or circumstances other than those to which it is held invalid, shall not be affected thereby, and it is hereby declared that such sections and provisions would have been passed independently of such section or provision so known to be invalid. 
(Ord. No. 1264, § 6-221, 1-14-03) 
Sec. 11-181. - Conflicting articles repealed. 
    All articles or parts of articles in conflict with the provisions of this article are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 1264, § 6-222, 1-14-03) 
Sec. 11-182. - Effective date. 
    This article shall be enforced from and after March 1, 2003. 
(Ord. No. 1264, § 6-223, 1-14-03) 
Secs. 11-183-11-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - REGULATION OF TRANSIENT AND OPEN-AIR BUSINESSES 

Sec. 11-200. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety and welfare by reducing the creation of unsafe conditions and circumstances on public and private property, to discourage the sale of inferior quality merchandise, to require disclosure of adequate information to accurately identify persons and entities to establish a requirement for jurisdiction and service of process for civil claims, to require posting of a security bond, to provide requirements for sales records and receipts and written evidence and filings of reports of all transactions and to provide a method for enforcement of violations of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-201. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, unless the context clearly otherwise requires or unless otherwise defined in specific portions of the article, the following words shall have the respective meanings ascribed to each in this section: 
    Business means any business, trade or occupation unless exempted hereinafter. 
    City means the City of Crowley. 
    Event . An event shall consist of any transaction involving the sale, solicitation, taking orders or offering for sale of goods within the corporate limits. An event shall commence at 12:00 a.m. on the date stated on the license/permit as the beginning date and shall end at 11:59 p.m. on the date stated on the license/permit. The applicant shall request a commencement date and ending date which may be approved or changed by the clerk. 
    Merchandise means any consumer item, new or used, wares, goods, food, food products, plants, paintings, mirrors, artifacts or any sellable product except for the items listed hereafter. 
    Open-air merchant means any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other association, including agents, representatives and employees thereof, who exhibits merchandise, including models or samples thereof, in, upon or about a vehicle, mobile unit or other means of conveyance, cart, stand, temporary building, portable unit or tent, whether enclosed or unenclosed, or who exhibits such merchandise on any private street, driveway, lot, parking lot or other outdoor property within the City of Crowley, for the purpose of selling, offering to sell or taking orders for the sale of such merchandise. 
    Peddler . For the purpose of this article, a peddler means any person who, for himself or any other person, goes from house to house, or place to place, or store to store, exposing and selling the merchandise which he carries with him and delivering same at the time of or immediately after the sale or without returning to the base of business operation between the taking of the order and the delivery of the goods; however, any person who uses the same vehicle or a combination of one or more vehicles for the purpose of taking orders and delivering merchandise, regardless of the fact that the vehicle returns to the base of operations between the taking of the order and the delivery of the merchandise, shall be deemed a peddler, unless such person can show that the merchandise delivered is accompanied by an invoice or delivery ticket prepared at the base of operations and which conforms to the original order and that the person delivering the merchandise has permitted no deviation from the original order by allowing the purchaser to reject, cancel, increase or decrease the quantity at the time of delivery or to offset against such quantity any merchandise delivered at a prior time which is being returned. This extension of the meaning of the term peddler shall not be interpreted so as to prevent rejection or cancellation of bona fide orders or the return of inferior merchandise, but shall be construed so as to prevent persons peddling merchandise from escaping their tax liability by subterfuge through means of so-called "standing order" or blanket advance orders, increase and decrease in quantities at the time of delivery, arbitrary rejections and cancellations, and offset of merchandise returned by reason of non-sale rather than obligation of warranty, all of which are hereby declared to be mere devices to prevent normal methods of operations so as to disguise the business of a peddler as an ordinary wholesale business. Peddler shall include but is not limited to hawkers, itinerant vendors, and any retail dealers not having a fixed place of business. 
    Person means an individual, firm, corporation, partnership, association or other legal entity. 
    Separate location means a separate location exists unless a similar or associated type of business is operated as a unit (single license) under a single roof or on the same contiguous tract or land. 
    Transient merchant means any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other association, including agents, representatives and employees thereof, who exhibits merchandise, including models or samples thereof, in any hotel or motel room, rooming house, store, club, storehouse, house, or other permanent building structure, for the purpose of selling, offering to sell or taking orders for the sale of such merchandise. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11; Ord. No. 1436, § 1, 6-12-12) 
Sec. 11-202. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other unincorporated association having a licensed permanent retail location in the City of Crowley provided that: 
(1)  The name of such licensed retail business is used in connection with all merchandise sold or offered for sale. 
(2)  All vendees are notified that all merchandise is sold under the auspices of said licensed permanent retail business. 
(3)  The name of the licensed permanent establishment is clearly included in all advertisements in connection with the sale of such merchandise. 
(4)  The owner or owners of the licensed retail establishment expressly assume responsibility for all merchandise sold within the establishment, building or structure, or on the same parcel of property whether sold from a vehicle, mobile unit or other means of conveyance, cart, stand, temporary building, portable unit or tent, whether enclosed or unenclosed. 
(b)  The provision of this article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Sales of meat, seafood, vegetables, fruit or perishable farm products. 
(2)  Sales of handcrafted items at arts and crafts shows, fairs or festivals sponsored by a Louisiana nonprofit corporation. 
(3)  Sales made at events commonly known as flea markets, stamp shows, coin shows, arts and crafts shows, trade shows or other exhibitions, provided the manager, promoter, coordinator or other persons in authority for such market, show or exhibition and with the applicable requirements of the City of Crowley. 
(4)  Authorized sales by participating vendors on fairgrounds during a local or parish fair. 
(5)  Sales of soft drinks or refreshments. 
(6)  Sales of secondhand or used clothing. 
(7)  Sales of cut flowers. 
(8)  Sales of balloons and other trinket items at parades and circuses, provided that the sponsor of the parade or circus has obtained the proper permit and authorization from the City of Crowley. 
(9)  Sales of handcrafted items made or produced by an individual who has obtained a valid home-occupation license from the City of Crowley as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-203. - Annual license tax. 
    There is hereby levied an annual license tax, as specified under the provisions of section 11-1 of this chapter, upon each person acting as a transient merchant or open-air merchant in the City of Crowley who may be subject to such license under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-204. - License required; payment of fees and charges; annual license; limitation of events. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or legal entity to transact any business or phase of business in the City of Crowley, including advertising, without first applying to the City of Crowley for a license or permit required by this chapter. 
(b)  Payment of the annual license fee and any additional charges for application for license/permit shall be paid before the license is issued. 
(c)  The annual peddler's license/permit shall be valid during the period of January 1st to December 31st of each calendar year. The license/permit shall be valid for a maximum of ten (10) days during the calendar year and may be used for not more than three (3) separate events as defined herein. No event shall last more than ten (10) days, consecutively or cumulative. During the calendar year, the license/permit may be used for a single event of ten (10) days or up to three (3) separate events as defined herein not to exceed a total of ten (10) days. Thereafter, the license/permit shall no longer be valid for the remainder of the calendar year. The license/permit shall expire at 11:59 p.m. on the tenth day designated on the license/permit on the third event, whichever shall occur first. 
(d)  Applicant shall request a commencement date and end date for each event which shall be approved by the clerk and stated on the license/permit. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11; Ord. No. 1436, § 2, 6-12-12) 
Sec. 11-205. - Application for license/permit. 
(a)  Every person or legal entity subject to the provisions of this section, before selling at retail or offering for sale at retail within the incorporated limits of the City of Crowley any goods, wares or merchandise, either from stock or by sample, shall make application with the City of Crowley for a license/permit to conduct such business within the City of Crowley. Such application shall be in writing, duly sworn by the applicant in person, or by the applicant's duly authorized representative, and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, complete address and telephone number of the person having the management, supervision or ownership of such business. 
(2)  The name, complete address, telephone number and local address or location of the person having supervision of the licenses premises while engaged in such business in the city. 
(3)  Photocopy of a valid driver's license, valid identification card, military identification issued by a governmental agency of any state or United States. In the event such form of identification cannot be provided, the permit shall not be issued. 
(4)  The capacity and authority in which such person will act; that is, whether as proprietor, agent or employee. 
(5)  The name, complete address and telephone number of the person or legal entity for whose account the business shall be conducting, and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is incorporated. 
(6)  The complete address of the permanent or established business location of the person, legal entity or owner of the business. 
(7)  The complete address, legal description or other identifying information in the city where the applicant proposes to engage in such business, the name, complete address and telephone number of the owner of the property on which the business is to be conducted, a copy of the lease or other instrument authorizing the use of the property by the owner stating all terms and conditions required thereon. 
(8)  A list of all places or locations, other than the permanent place of business of the owner, where such transient merchant or open-air merchant within the six (6) months next preceding the date of such application conducted or carried on a temporary or transitory business, stating the nature thereof and giving the complete street addresses and locations of any building or structure on which such business was conducted. 
(9)  a.  The applicant shall designate the commencement date of door to door sales or solicitation or the open display for sale or taking orders shall begin and the last date of the event if less than ten (10) days from the commencement date. Otherwise, the end date shall be the tenth day after the commencement date and shall be entered on the application and the license/permit. 
b.  The applicant may specify commencement and ending dates for more than one event not to exceed three (3) separate events as designated by commencement and ending dates so long as the cumulative number of days does not exceed ten (10) and no more than three (3) events. Under no circumstances shall the number of commencement and ending dates exceed the total of three (3) events and a cumulative total of the event days exceed the maximum stated herein. 
c.  The dates shown on the license/permit issued may be changed upon written request to the city clerk. All requests for changes of the event commencement and ending dates and/or the number of events must be received not less than thirty (30) days prior to the date requested. Upon receipt of a timely request, the city clerk shall issue an amendment to the license/permit which shall state the commencement and ending dates of the event/events requested and the amendment shall be attached to the original license/permit and displayed as required herein. 
(10)  A statement of the nature, character and quantity of the goods, wares or merchandise to be sold at retail, offered to be sold at retail or taking orders to be sold at retail in the city, including the brand name or manufacturer's name, and the gross amount of the merchandise at invoice costs of such merchandise. 
(11)  A statement as to whether the goods are to be sold at retail from stock in possession or ordered by sample, whether delivery is to occur at the time of sale at the retail location and whether the same are to be sold at retail at auction or public outcry, or by personal solicitation, or otherwise. 
(12)  A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done or to be done in order to attract customers and the media or method used to disseminate said advertising. 
(13)  The names of all sales personnel or employees who have committed crimes within the past five (5) years, the number of arrests or convictions of misdemeanors or crimes, and the nature of the offenses for which arrested or convicted, if any. 
(14)  To the application must be appended a letter from the firm for which the applicant purports to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as its representative. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any transient merchant, vendor, solicitor, peddler or canvasser to engage in business until he shall have first applied to and obtained a permit to engage in business, in accordance with the above provisions and has paid all taxes and fees required by law for the transaction of such business in the incorporated limits of the City of Crowley; the City of Crowley shall issue such permit in writing which state the date same was issued, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on and the expiration date of such permit, the place where such business may be carried on under such permit, and the name of the person or persons authorized to carry on the same, which permit shall be signed by the City of Crowley or its authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11; Ord. No. 1436, § 3, 6-12-12) 
Sec. 11-206. - General regulations and restrictions. 
    No licensee/permittee shall operate in the following areas of public space or specified distances therefrom: 
(a)  On or within a public street, boulevard, highway, roadway, alleyway, right-of-way, park, parking lot, emergency lane, neutral ground, shoulder, public building or facility or any other public property dedicated for a specific use situated within the city or on private property except specifically authorized by this article. 
(b)  Within ten (10) feet of any street intersection or pedestrian crosswalk. 
(c)  Within ten (10) feet of any public or private driveway, loading zone or bus stop. 
(d)  In any location which will not leave a minimum of five (5) feet of unobstructed pedestrian space or such greater amount of space, private building or structure. 
(e)  In any area within twenty (20) feet of a building entrance or exit. 
(f)  On the median strip of a divided roadway. 
(g)  Within twenty (20) feet of any fire hydrant, fire escape or designated fire lane. 
(h)  Within ten (10) feet of any private or public parking space or access ramp designated for persons with disabilities. 
(i)  On the premises of a festival or special event as defined in the written rules and regulations, or on the grounds of any public park, facility, recreation center or multipurpose facilities, except in conjunction with a festival or special public event. 
(j)  No such transactions shall be conducted on any area of private property within ten (10) feet of the property line of the licensed/permitted location. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-207. - Issuance of permit. 
    No permit shall be issued until the expiration of ten (10) days from the date of application and after proper investigation of said applicant and provided said applicant meets all requirements herein set forth and has complied with all other applicable ordinances. The permit issued shall be valid for a period of duration of the sale. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-208. - Location of operation. 
    No licensee/permittee shall operate except in the specific location, address or description designated on the license/permit. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-209. - Designation of merchandise. 
    No licensee/permittee shall sell, offer for sale, exhibit for sale or exhibit for the purpose of taking orders for the sale thereof, any goods or merchandise other than the merchandise, goods or wares designated on the license/permit. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-210. - Hours of operation; door to door/outdoor display and illumination and security requirements. 
(a)  No licensee/permittee shall conduct door to door sales or solicitations for sales, or orders for delivery of goods or merchandise or by entering onto private property and/or knocking on doors of private residences or businesses before the hour of 9:00 a.m. or after 6:00 p.m. or sunset, whichever shall occur first. 
(b)  No licensee/permittee utilizing outdoor display, whether from open vehicles, trailers, tents or otherwise, shall exhibit for sale, offer for sale, solicit orders for the sale or delivery of any goods or merchandise or conduct any sales or transactions before the hour of 7:00 a.m. or after the hour of 6:00 p.m. or sunset, whichever occurs first. 
(c)  The licensee/permittee utilizing outdoor display, whether from open vehicles, trailers, tents or otherwise, shall exhibit for sale, offer for sale, solicit orders for the sale or delivery of any goods or merchandise or conduct any sales or transactions, may continue operations and transactions until the hour of 10:00 p.m. only when the location of the display of goods and merchandise specified in the license/permit is illuminated by permanent security lights providing sufficient illumination to illuminate the area designated as the location of the display of goods and merchandise and the entire parking lot. 
(d)  All goods and merchandise displayed outdoors shall be secured in a vehicle, trailer, cargo box or otherwise not later than 10:30 p.m. and outdoor displays utilizing tents or other nonsecured structure shall have sides or flaps which can be closed and reasonable secured with all goods and merchandise placed therein with twenty-four-hour security lights. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11; Ord. No. 1436, § 4, 6-12-12) 
Sec. 11-211. - Cleanliness of premises; litter receptacles required/maintained. 
    The licensee/permittee must keep the area upon which they conduct the sale of merchandise and those areas immediately adjacent thereto free from all refuse, litter and trash. The licensee/permittee shall be responsible to collect all trash and debris attributable to their business activity or caused by their business activity and to deposit same into an appropriate trash container. The licensee/permittee shall provide a sufficient number of trash receptacles for litter which shall be clearly marked and maintained and emptied regularly. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-212. - Ingress and egress; compliance with law enforcement. 
    No licensee/permittee shall conduct his business in such a way as would restrict or interfere with the ingress or egress of the abutting property owner or tenant, create a nuisance, increase traffic congestion or delay, constitute a hazard to traffic, life or property, or obstruct adequate access to emergency and sanitation vehicles. The licensee/permittee shall comply with the instructions of a law enforcement officer or fire department officer to move from a location in the interest of public safety. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-213. - Zoning. 
    No license/permit issued herein shall be construed as having an affect on zoning, historic district, special district or other regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-214. - Bonding. 
    Before such license is issued by the City of Crowley, the applicant will be required to furnish a performance bond in an amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). Such bond will be held by the City of Crowley for a period of ninety (90) days after all orders of goods, wares and retail merchandise have been delivered to the persons from whom the orders are taken, to assure delivery of said orders to the satisfaction of such persons, and to be in compliance with the specifications stated in the order and meeting the requirements of the solicitations and advertisements. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-215. - Placard required. 
    Prior to the conducting of the business activity under this article, the licensee/permittee must submit to the City of Crowley the permit secured from the sheriff and secure from the city a permit placard not less than three (3) feet by three (3) feet and no more than six (6) feet by six (6) feet which shall contain the trade name of the vendor, the authorized location, and the year of authorization together with the parish authorization to conduct such business activity which placard must be displayed conspicuously at the location at all times during the conduct of the business. The licensee/permittee must provide a photograph of said placard. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-216. - Inspection. 
    Immediately upon issuing any permit provided for above, the city clerk, city inspector or any designated representative may at any time thereafter and at all reasonable hours make an inspection of the place of business as provided in said permit. The city inspector shall determine whether or not such business is carried on or conducted by the person or persons and in the manner provided in the permit, and the application upon which the permit was issued, and whether or not the other provisions of this article are being observed in the carrying on of such business. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-217. - Prices to be posted. 
    All vendors under this article must have the minimum and maximum price of the merchandise, wares, goods, food, food products, seafood of any kind, beverages, plants, flowers, paintings, mirrors, or any artifact or saleable product whatsoever posted conspicuously on a sign no smaller than three (3) feet by five (5) feet and no larger than six (6) feet by eight (8) feet. No other signs, except one permit placard, shall be permitted. The licensee/permittee must provide a photograph of said placard. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-218. - Record of sales. 
(a)  Each licensee/permittee shall maintain a separate register, book, ledger or other means of identifying transactions in an electronic format which shall be maintained for a period of three (3) years and shall be made available for inspection by any police officer, law enforcement official, inspector or sales tax/license tax/permit official at any time. All daily records shall consist of the transaction log recording each individual transaction or sale, identifying the item sold, the description of the item sold, the number thereof sold, the amount of the transaction, the amount of sales taxes charged and the amount collected. 
(b)  The licensee/permittee shall issue and deliver a receipt of each transaction to each customer. Daily records shall be compiled in electronic form and transmitted via email to the office of the city clerk or may be transferred onto a disc or copies made of ledgers or books shall be hand delivered or mailed via United States mail prepaid and properly addressed to the office of the city clerk no later than twenty-four (24) hours of the termination of the sales event or occupancy and for each occupancy or occurrence thereafter for the term of the annual license. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-219. - Violations. 
    The violation of any of the foregoing provisions or the doing of business otherwise than provided in the application and permit issued thereon shall each constitute a violation of the license/permit and the City of Crowley may suspend the operation of such permit not to exceed ten (10) days and upon the request of the holder of such license/permit, grant a hearing and rule upon such violation. Should the City of Crowley find that there has been a violation of the conditions of the license/permit, such license/permit shall be immediately forfeited, surrendered and cancelled. A forfeiture of the license/permit shall not entitle the licensee/permittee to any refund of taxes or fees paid. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Sec. 11-220. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any licensee/permittee who fails to obtain said license/permit or to comply with any regulations contained herein shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be imprisoned for a period of not more than sixty (60) days or fined the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00) or both, at the discretion of the court. A licensee/permittee so convicted shall forfeit said license/permit and shall not be entitled to a refund of the fees paid therefor. Every day that a violation of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 1431, § 1, 12-13-11) 
Chapter 12 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Use of city-owned vehicles generally, § 2-9; liability for damage to city property, § 2-10. 
Editor's note- The city personnel are members of the state municipal retirement system. See ordinances on file in city clerk's office. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Employment preference for residents of the city. 
(a)  The city does hereby declare its policy to employ persons who reside within the corporate limits of the city to provide employment opportunity for residents of the city and to insure the availability of employees for duty on short notice and for emergencies. 
(b)  The city shall employ persons who actually reside within the corporate limits of the city provided all other considerations are equal. 
(Code 1965, § 2-22; Ord. No. 1176, § 1, 12-12-95; Ord. No. 1201, § 3, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 12-2. - Sick leave for non-civil service employees. 
(a)  All persons employed full-time by the city shall be entitled to ten (10) days sick leave during each calendar year, which leave may be accumulated for a three-year period for a term of thirty (30) full days if not used during the year which same accrues. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to civil service employees. 
(c)  Each full-time employee shall be granted not more than five (5) days personal leave annually which shall be subject to approval by the department head after written application requesting leave. Personal leave days may be used only during the calendar year earned and if not used during such year shall not accrue. 
(Code 1965, § 2-13; Ord. No. 1371, § 1, 8-14-07) 
Sec. 12-3. - Same-Application for; deduction from accumulation. 
    In the event that any employee entitled to sick leave suffers any illness or disability, the employee shall execute an application for sick leave on the forms to be furnished by the city. The periods of such illness or disability shall be deducted from the sick leave provided for hereinabove. 
(Code 1965, § 2-16) 
Sec. 12-4. - Same-Certification of application. 
    In the event that an illness or disability exists for a period of more than three (3) days, the application for sick leave shall be certified by the physician attending such employee. 
(Code 1965, § 2-17) 
Cross reference- See also § 12-10(6). 
Sec. 12-5. - Same-Disability exceeding. 
    For any period of illness or disability in excess of the current or accrued sick leave of any employee, a pro rata per diem deduction shall be made from the remuneration, pay or salary of such employee. 
(Code 1965, § 2-18) 
Sec. 12-6. - Same-Applying vacation against. 
    In the event that an employee has no sick leave remaining to such employee's credit, such employee may, by written request, apply any accrued vacation time against such period of disability, in order to avoid the deduction provided for in section 12-5. 
(Code 1965, § 2-19) 
Sec. 12-7. - Annual vacation; accumulation of vacation time; compensation in lieu of vacation and employee termination; city officials. 
(a)  After one year of employment with the city, each full-time city employee shall be entitled to one week paid vacation, which shall be taken within the next year of employment. After two (2) consecutive years of employment with the city, each employee shall be entitled to two (2) weeks annual vacation and for each year of employment thereafter. Annual vacation shall be earned upon the anniversary date of employment of each employee. 
(b)  Annual vacation shall not be accumulated and shall be taken each year after being earned, except any employee upon retirement may accumulate one year of annual vacation, earned in the year prior to retirement. 
(c)  Compensation in lieu of vacation shall not be paid, except upon the termination of an employee, any accumulated vacation time shall be paid together with any wages due as of the effective date of the employee's termination. 
(d)  Elected officials shall not be covered by this section. 
(Code 1965, § 2-15; Ord. No. 1268, § 1, 7-8-03) 
Sec. 12-8. - Effect of overtime. 
    In the event any employee described in section 12-2 works in excess of forty-eight (48) hours per week and thereby acquires an overtime credit, such employee shall be entitled to a compensatory leave of absence, with pay, which leave may be used by such employee as additional sick leave, additional vacation or for such other purpose as such employee deems advisable. Said compensatory leave may be accumulated during a period of not more than four (4) years. Provided, this section shall not be applicable to the chief executive officers of any of the departments of the municipal government, and their supervisory assistants, such as the chief of police, assistant chief of police, superintendent of the sewage disposal plant or assistant superintendent, chief of the fire department, assistant chief of the fire department, street commissioner or assistant street commissioner. 
(Code 1965, § 2-20) 
Sec. 12-9. - Application for leave of absence. 
    In the event any employee desires or requires a leave of absence, with or without pay, for any other purpose, such employee shall execute an application, requesting same and such application shall be acted upon by the governing authority at any regular or special meeting of the governing authority. 
(Code 1965, § 2-21) 
Sec. 12-10. - Dress requirements for members of police and fire departments; moonlighting; residence telephone; sick leave certification. 
    For the purpose of maintaining and increasing the efficiency of the members of the police and fire departments of the city and of the departments, the following rules and regulations governing such members are hereby established: 
(1)  All members of the departments, except clerical employees and special officers, when on duty, shall be attired in uniform, furnished at the expense and cost of each such member, the type and color to be designated by the chief of the department, and to consist of the following items: 
(a)  Police department: 
(i)  Summer uniform. Dress cap, black tie, summer shirt, summer trousers, black belt, black sox, black shoes, holster belt, hand gun, cap badge, breast badge, collar insignia; 
(ii)  Winter uniform. Dress cap, black tie, winter shirt, winter trousers, jacket, black belt, black sox, black shoes, holster belt, hand gun, cap badge, breast badge, collar insignia. 
(b)  Fire department: 
(i)  Summer uniform. Dress cap, black tie, summer shirt, summer trousers, black belt, black sox, black shoes, cap badge, breast badge, collar insignia; 
(ii)  Winter uniform. Dress cap, black tie, winter shirt, winter trousers, black belt, black sox, black shoes, cap badge, breast badge, collar insignia. 
(2)  Once designated, the type and color of the uniforms may be changed only by the governing authority; 
(3)  All items of such uniforms shall be maintained in a clean and neat condition and shall be repaired or replaced, by the employee, when damaged or worn, on the instructions of the chief of each department; 
(4)  Reserved. 
(5)  Each member of the departments shall maintain, at such member's expense, a telephone in such member's residence; 
(6)  No member of the departments shall be granted any sick leave or any pay for alleged period of illness or disability except upon the certification of such illness or disability by a qualified doctor of medicine or doctor of dentistry. 
(Code 1965, § 2-25; Ord. No. 1201, § 1, 4-8-97) 
Cross reference- See § 12-4 as to certification of sick leave application. 
Sec. 12-11. - Regulation and restriction of assignment of police personnel to overtime duty. 
    The chief of police of the city shall have full power to assign police personnel to duties, subject to the following limitations and provisions: 
(1)  Compliance by the chief of police with the provisions of any civil service statutes governing such personnel; 
(2)  Compliance with the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes, section 33:2213, as amended, establishing maximum regular hours of duty by police personnel; 
(3)  Only in the event of an emergency, the chief of police may assign personnel to overtime duty to the extent and for which the governing authority has budgeted and appropriated funds for the payment of overtime duty; 
(4)  As the governing authority is given full authority to control and manage the fiscal affairs of the municipality, no police personnel shall be assigned to overtime duty unless funds have been budgeted therefor and remain unexpended, unless such assignment to overtime duty is approved in writing by the mayor, or, in the mayor's absence, the mayor pro tem or by action of the governing body; 
(5)  In the event that chief of police deems it advisable to assign police personnel to overtime duty in the absence of an emergency, the chief shall make application to the governing authority for approval of such assignments and for the appropriation of the necessary funds to compensate such personnel for such overtime duty. 
(Code 1965, § 2-25.1) 
Sec. 12-12. - Use of police vehicles beyond corporate limits. 
    No police officer shall drive, operate or use any police vehicle acquired for use by the police department, beyond the corporate limits of the city except in line of official duty. 
(Code 1965, § 2-26.1) 
Cross reference- Use of city vehicles generally, § 2-9. 
Sec. 12-13. - Reserved. 
Sec. 12-14. - Hiring criteria for law enforcement personnel. 
(a)  All applicants for law enforcement positions where the person will be employed by the City of Crowley and issued a law enforcement commission shall consent to and undergo a psychological evaluation directed by the chief of police as part of the application process and shall consent to the results of said evaluation being provided to the chief of police and elected officials for the purposes of determining the suitability of the applicant for employment as a law enforcement officer. 
(b)  Any applicant refusing to consent to a psychological evaluation and to execute the necessary release forms as may be required by the provider shall be deemed unfit and ineligible for employment. 
(Ord. No. 1475, § 1, 6-14-16) 
Secs. 12-15-12-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVE POLICE FORCE 

Sec. 12-20. - Established. 
    The reserve police force of the city is hereby established, organized and regulated. 
(Code 1965, § 7-6; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-21. - Qualifications of applicants. 
    All applicants for membership in the reserve police force shall be: 
(1)  A citizen of the United States; 
(2)  A qualified elector of the state; 
(3)  Of good moral character and temperate and industrious habits; 
(4)  Not less than eighteen (18) years of age, nor more than fifty (50) years of age, at the time of original appointment; 
(5)  A high school graduate or possess a general equivalency diploma; 
(6)  The chief of police, in his sole discretion, may waive the educational requirements in subsection (5) upon written finding that the applicant's age, experience, training, performance and other relevant factors prove to the satisfaction to the chief of police that the applicant will otherwise be able to maintain the standards and qualifications of a reserve police officer; 
(7)  In the event the chief of police waives educational requirements pursuant to subsection (6) above, the applicant shall immediately enroll in a state certified educational program to obtain an general equivalency diploma (GED) which shall be completed within one year of the date of the applicant's appointment. 
(Code 1965, § 7-7; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95; Ord. No. 1482, § 1, 12-7-16) 
Sec. 12-22. - Appointment of personnel. 
    The following procedure shall be followed in the appointment of personnel to the reserve police force: 
(1)  All applications shall be in writing, or a form to be furnished by the city; 
(2)  The governing authority shall make all appointments to said organization after consultation with the chief of police and police committee; 
(3)  All initial appointments of personnel shall be for a probationary period of six (6) months, subject to confirmation of or revocation of such probationary appointment thereafter. Failure of the governing authority to revoke such probationary appointment within three (3) months after such probationary period has expired shall constitute confirmation of such appointment. 
(Code 1965, § 7-8; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-23. - Total authorized strength. 
    The governing authority shall provide, by motion, from time to time, the total authorized strength of the reserve police force. 
(Code 1965, § 7-9; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-24. - Discharge at age sixty-five. 
    Upon any member of the force reaching the age of sixty-five (65), such member shall be discharged from active duty and shall be entitled to honorary membership in the organization. 
(Code 1965, § 7-10; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-25. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 1201, adopted April 8, 1997, repealed § 12-25 in its entirety. Former § 12-25 pertained to resignations from the police force and derived from the 1965 Code, § 7-11 and Ord. No. 1165, § 1, adopted May 9, 1995. 
Sec. 12-26. - Discipline or dismissal. 
    Any reserve police officer may be disciplined or dismissed for any cause for which a regular police officer of the city may be disciplined or dismissed under the procedure hereinafter provided: 
(1)  Written charges against such officer shall be filed with the city clerk and submitted to the governing authority; 
(2)  Said officer shall be served with written notification of the filing of such charges and a true copy thereof not less than ten (10) days prior to any action thereon by the governing authority; 
(3)  Such officer may apply in writing for a hearing before the governing authority and may request that such hearing be either private or public; 
(4)  In the event that application is made for a hearing, no action shall be taken on the charges until after the hearing is held; 
(5)  The mayor shall set the date for the hearing and shall notify the officer of such date. 
(Code 1965, § 7-12; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-27. - Positions or ranks. 
    The positions or ranks of the reserve police force shall correspond to those of the regular police, except that the rank of the commanding officer of such reserve police shall be that of "commandant", but no such position or rank shall bear a higher designation than those of the regular police and, in addition thereto, one (1) member of the organization shall be named and designated as "executive officer" to assist the reserve police commandant in the internal operation of the organization, provided that the wearing of any insignia, badge or other indication or evidence of rank by any reserve police officer while such person is on duty in the city is prohibited and shall constitute grounds for disciplinary action. 
(Code 1965, § 7-13; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-28. - Promotions. 
    The governing authority shall make all promotions of personnel of the force in the following manner: 
(1)  All promotions shall be made from the next lower rank and only upon need of additional personnel in the higher position; 
(2)  The police committee shall consult with the chief of police and the chief of the reserve police force and make recommendations on promotions to the governing authority prior to action by such body; 
(3)  All patrolmen shall be promoted to patrolman first class after one (1) year of service in the reserve. 
(Code 1965, § 7-14; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-29. - Command. 
    When on active duty with the police department of the city, all reserve police officers shall be under the immediate command of the ranking regular police officer on the scene and the overall command of the chief of police. 
(Code 1965, § 7-15; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-30. - Rights, privileges, etc. 
    When on active duty with the police department of the city, the reserve police officers shall have all the rights, privileges, immunities and powers provided by statutes or ordinances for police officers of the department and by any applicable statute governing or regulating reserve police. 
(Code 1965, § 7-16; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-31. - Attendance of classes and instruction. 
    All reserve police personnel shall attend such classes and instruction as required by the municipal authorities and the minimum requirements of state civil defense regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 7-17; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-32. - Reporting for duty. 
    Members of such force, when reporting for duty, shall be properly attired, which attire shall be clean, neat and in good repair, and such personnel shall act as police officers only when called to duty by the chief of police or, in the chief's absence or inability to act, the mayor or acting mayor, and only under the command of the chief of police or senior police officer on duty. 
(Code 1965, § 7-18; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-33. - Failure to report for duty. 
    Failure to report for duty on three (3) occasions within any calendar year, without valid cause or conflict with employment, shall constitute grounds for disciplinary action against any member of the force. 
(Code 1965, § 7-19; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-34. - Care and return of equipment. 
    Each member of the force shall be liable for the care and return, in good condition, of all equipment issued to such member and shall be liable for loss thereof or damage thereto, ordinary wear and tear excepted. 
(Code 1965, § 7-20; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-35. - Application for position on police force. 
    All members of the detachment shall be accorded particular consideration, subject to the provisions of the civil service law, upon applying for a position in the police force. 
(Code 1965, § 7-21; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Sec. 12-36. - Citations and ribbons. 
    The following citations and accompanying ribbons designed to be worn on their uniform shall be awarded to members of the detachment for meritorious service: 
(1)  Certificate of appreciation, signed by the mayor and chief of police, awarded for one (1) year of honorable service and completion of basic training; 
(2)  Certificate of merit, signed by the mayor and chief of police, awarded for five (5) years of honorable service; 
(3)  Certificate of honor, signed by the mayor and chief of police, awarded for ten (10) years of honorable service; 
(4)  Honorable discharge. This award shall be presented to members who have completed not less than ten (10) years of honorable service, or reached retirement age, upon retirement or release from service for whatever cause so long as the release is honorable and not punitive. 
(Code 1965, § 7-22; Ord. No. 1165, § 1, 5-9-95) 
Secs. 12-37-12-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SUPPLEMENTAL PAY PLAN-MUNICIPAL POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS 

Sec. 12-50. - Supplemental pay allowance. 
    There is hereby established a supplemental allowance to provide for the standardization and synchronization of pay of probationary police officers and firemen from the date upon which they are hired until the date upon which the probationary shall be qualified for state supplemental pay, which shall hereby be known as the "city supplemental pay allowance". 
(Ord. No. 1208, §§ 1, 2, 5-12-98) 
Sec. 12-51. - Not to be considered base pay. 
    The city's supplemental pay allowance it not to be considered or construed, in whole or part, as base pay. Any discontinuance of same, whether as a result of the officer's receipt of state supplemental pay or provisions to pay, shall merely constitute a cessation of a special benefit and not a reduction of the city salary. 
(Ord. No. 1208, §§ 1, 2, 5-12-98) 
Sec. 12-52. - Determining gross salary. 
    For the purpose complying with the applicable statutes identifying state supplemental pay as "salary" for determining overtime rates, holiday pay, longevity increases, tax deductions and retirement plan contributions, such special benefit known as the city supplemental pay allowance shall be identified and included as gross salary for such purposes as provided in the state supplemental pay plan. Such gross salary will determine general increases and other benefits including salary adjustments for longevity, leave of absence, suspensions without pay or other similar actions. 
(Ord. No. 1208, §§ 1, 2, 5-12-98) 
Sec. 12-53. - The amount of payment. 
    For the purposes of computing the amount of the city supplemental pay allowance, the amount of supplemental pay to be paid as a special benefit by the city is the maximum amount of state supplemental pay as provided by Louisiana Statutes 33:2218.1 et seq. Said supplemental pay shall be increased by the same amount as provided by amendment to the state supplemental pay plan. 
(Ord. No. 1208, §§ 1, 2, 5-12-98) 
Sec. 12-54. - Suspension or termination of plan. 
    The city may suspend and/or terminate this special benefits of the city supplemental pay allowance at any time and such cessation or termination of the special benefit shall not constitute a reduction in gross salary. 
(Ord. No. 1208, §§ 1, 2, 5-12-98) 
Chapter 13 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Moving buildings over streets, § 5-140 et seq.; barbed wire prohibited along streets, § 7-5; obstruction of drainage, § 9-21. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Numbering of buildings-Duty of property holders. 
    It is hereby made the duty of each property holder to number or have numbered any dwellings or business hours belonging to such person within the limits of the city in conformance herewith. 
(Code 1965, § 20-36) 
Sec. 13-2. - Same-System. 
(a)  Beginning at Parkerson Avenue, and extending east and west, all streets shall be numbered with the even numbers on the right side and odd numbers on the left side, and beginning at the Southern Pacific Railroad, and extending both north and south, all avenues shall be numbered with the even numbers on the right side and odd numbers on the left side. Said numbers shall be based upon one number for each twenty (20) feet of frontage and the numbers on streets and avenues north of Southern Pacific Railroad shall begin from Front Street and the first block shall contain numbers 1 to 99; from First Street to Second Street 100 to 199; Second Street to Third Street 200 to 299; Third Street to Fourth Street 300 to 399; Fourth Street to Fifth Street 400 to 499; Fifth Street to Sixth Street, Hutchinson Avenue intervening 500 to 599; continuing with 100 numbers to each block; except blocks from 13th Street to 14th Street, Northern Avenue intervening shall contain numbers 1300 to 1399; 14th Street to 15th Street 1400 to 1499, etc.; and where acreage or unplatted areas exist between two (2) platted areas, the numbering shall be continued as hereinabove set forth and each three hundred sixty (360) feet of such unplatted areas shall be considered one block and intervening street. 
(b)  The numbers of the streets running east and west shall start from Parkerson Avenue, both north and south Crowley, the first block east and west of said avenue shall contain numbers from 100 to 199, and the second block from 200 to 299 and continuing with 100 numbers for each block to the limits of the city, east and west, and where acreage or unplatted areas exist between two (2) platted areas, the numbering shall be continued as hereinabove set forth and each three hundred eighty (380) feet of such unplatted area or areas shall be considered one block and intervening street. 
(c)  The numbers of streets and avenues in south Crowley running north and south shall begin at Mill Street, and the block to 14th Street (now Clay Street) shall contain numbers 300 to 399, to 15th Street (now Cedar Street) 400 to 499; to 16th Street (now Oak Street ) 500 to 599; continuing with 100 numbers to each block to the southern limits of the city, and where acreage or unplatted areas exist between two (2) platted areas, the numbering shall be continued as hereinabove set forth and each three hundred sixty (360) feet of such unplatted area or areas shall be considered one block and intervening street. 
(Code 1965, § 20-37) 
Sec. 13-3. - Same-Requirements for numbers. 
    Street numbers shall be provided and installed by the property owner or occupant and shall be no less than two (2) inches in height. They shall be clearly visible from the street. 
(Code 1965, § 20-38) 
Sec. 13-4. - Same-Provisions to be filed; future maps to conform. 
    A copy of sections 13-1 through 13-3 shall be recorded in the public records of this parish, and all future maps of the city shall be made to conform herewith. 
(Code 1965, § 20-39) 
Sec. 13-5. - Defacing, damaging streets. 
    It shall be unlawful to deface or damage in any manner whatsoever, any of the paved streets or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 20-1) 
Cross reference- Heavy vehicles on asphalt streets, § 14-2. 
Sec. 13-6. - Burning prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to burn trash, leaves, grass or any other combustible material on any of the paved streets or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 20-2) 
Cross reference- Burning trash in open areas, § 8-5. 
Sec. 13-7. - Spilling gasoline, oil. 
    It shall be unlawful to pour or spill gasoline, oil or any other similar substances on any of the paved streets or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 20-3) 
Sec. 13-8. - Duty to trim trees over sidewalks. 
(a)  All property owners in the city shall be required to trim the branches of trees on their property and on the banquette abutting their property so as to leave an unobstructed space at least seven (7) feet high over the sidewalks. 
(b)  Any person or persons failing to comply with this section shall be notified by the street commissioner and given a reasonable time in which to comply, and failure to comply with said notice shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1965, § 20-4) 
Cross reference- Tree regulations generally, § 5-150 et seq. 
Sec. 13-9. - Obstructions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain, or cause the placing or maintaining, of any material, item or thing which in any way obstructs or impedes the use of any street or sidewalk; provided, that temporary obstructions, such as, but not limited to, the loading and unloading of merchandise or during building operations, shall be allowed upon permission granted by the police chief. The police chief may attach reasonable conditions to such permission, such as, but not limited to: 
(1)  The size or extent of such obstruction. 
(2)  The location of the obstruction. 
(3)  The duration of the obstruction. 
(4)  Required safety precautions. 
(Code 1965, § 20-37) 
Cross reference- Railroad train blocking crossing, § 14-30. 
State Law reference- Obstructing public passage, R.S. 14:100.1. 
Sec. 13-10. - Paving and repair of railroad track crossings. 
(a)  Railroad companies operating in the city, whose tracks are laid on or across the public roads, highways or streets of the city, shall keep in good repair and suitable for vehicular traffic, with hard surfacing, that portion of such public way lying between the rails of such railroad tracks and for a distance of two (2) feet on the outside of each rail of the tracks used or operated by then, together with the necessary headers. 
(b)  The railroad grade crossings, when in need of replacement or major repair, shall be rubber pads or timber railroad crossings, including the space between the rails, and shall conform to the existing and future street, road or highway construction. The timbers used in any such crossings shall be treated with creosote or other preservative. 
(c)  Whenever any railroad shall have two (2) or more railroad tracks on or across any such road, highway or street, the entire space between all of the tracks shall be hard-surfaced and kept in good repair at all times and shall be of the same width as the connecting public way and conform to Louisiana State Highway Specifications, September 7, 1972, "Railroad Highway Grade Crossings Policy," a copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk, or with common standard specifications of said railroad company, whichever has the higher standards. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any railroad company to suffer or permit its crossings over public streets, highways and roads in the city to fall into a state of disrepair or to violate any of the provisions of this section. 
(e)  Failure of any railroad company, officer, managing agent or other supervising agent, to repair and maintain the tracks of the railroad across or on any streets, roads or highways in the city in the manner set forth hereinabove, shall be prima facie evidence of the violation of this section. 
(f)  Each day any violation of any provision of this section continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 20-7) 
Sec. 13-11. - Posting notices, advertisements, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful to tack or nail to any pole, post, fence or building upon or abutting upon the streets of the city, any card, circular, poster, paper or advertisement of any kind. 
(Code 1965, § 8-36) 
Secs. 13-12-13-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS AND CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES WITHIN PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY AND STREETS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1231, adopted April 1, 2000, amended and re-enacted Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the 1965 Code, §§ 20-17-20-25 and Ord. No. 1196, adopted Mar. 11, 1997. 

Sec. 13-20. - Permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities, private or public, to make any excavation, cut or opening or boring below any street, alley, shoulder, sidewalk, banquette, median, boulevard, neutral ground, curb or gutter, ditch or planting space located within public right-of-way in the City of Crowley, hereinafter "street", or conduct construction activities upon or adjacent to street pavement without first obtaining a permit from the City of Crowley, hereinafter, "city". 
(b)  Hereinafter, the word "city" shall mean the city limits in the context of location, and shall mean the mayor, inspector or duly authorized representative in the context of person. 
(c)  In the event emergency repairs are necessary to restore or maintain service, the entity making the emergency repairs need not obtain a permit in advance of making said repairs; but shall comply with all other applicable provisions of these regulations. The city building inspector, hereinafter "inspector", shall be notified of the emergency by telephone before any such work commences. The city shall be formally notified and the permit shall be obtained at the first reasonable opportunity after such emergency repairs have commended. No permit shall be required when any person has been awarded a public contract pursuant to the laws of the State of Louisiana for the construction of improvements on behalf of the city. The City of Crowley department shall not be required to obtain a permit for right of way excavation outside pavement areas, but all city work shall adhere to construction specifications contained herein. 
(Ord. No. 1231, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-21. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to excavate, cut open or bore under shall make written application for a permit on forms provided for said purpose in the office of the city inspector. 
(b)  The applicant shall provide full name, address and telephone number, the exact location of the proposed work or description of the proposed work, the purpose of the proposed work and a schematic diagram shall be drawn as near to scale as possible and shall submit sufficient data, plans, specifications or drawings which shall clearly define the proposed work and the plans for street right of way restoration. 
(c)  The permit shall be secured prior to the commencement of all work, except as provided for under an emergency. 
(d)  Any work or excavation within the public rights-of-way which is conducted without a permit shall be stopped and no further work shall be allowed to recommence until the proper permit has been issued for said work. 
(e)  It shall be the obligation of all applicants to make investigations necessary to locate all underground utilities, structures, pipelines, and conduits in the area in which work is contemplated. 
(f)  The permittee shall maintain and protect any and all existing structures and utilities within the limits of the work area or as reasonably near thereto. 
(g)  The City of Crowley shall determine whether such plans and drawings are sufficient and require existing detail of other utility locations and the opinion of the work to justify such a requirement. 
(h)  No deposit shall be required for a permit to perform work within city right-of-way. However, the permittee is fully responsible to restore the work area to a condition as good or better than the original condition. 
(i)  It shall be the duty and obligation of the permittee to safeguard the public by maintaining the necessary guards, barricades and safety lights, etc., in accordance with law and the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, latest edition, hereinafter MUTCD. The permittee shall maintain the street in a good and safe condition. The permittee shall hold harmless and indemnify the city from any and all claims, causes of action, lawsuits, damages to property, person or death, or as a result of such work by the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 1231, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-22. - Installation requirements. 
(a)  General. 
(1)  All utility owners, contractors, construction crews, equipment operators, etc., herein referred to as "permittee", shall be prohibited from placing any construction equipment directly on the street pavement at any time without an approved means of protecting the street surface. Rubber tire equipment will generally be approved as protective of the street surface. Permittees shall be prohibited from depositing any spoil and/or other construction materials (unprotected) on the street pavement at any time before, during or after the initiation of such activities, except that the holder of a utility franchise issued by the City of Crowley shall be exempt from this requirement, so long as permittee's actions in conducting such operations cause no harm or damage to the street or street pavement. All wheels, cleats, matting or other such protective barriers used for preservation of the existing street pavement shall require prior approval from the city. 
(2)  All street pavement shall be bored and no street pavement shall be removed except otherwise provided herein. Where applicable, borings shall begin at the outfall end of the pipe whenever possible. Suitable pits or trenches shall be evacuated at each end of the bore hole for the purpose of conducting the operations and for placing the joints of pipe. Adequate sheeting and bracing shall be provided on the pavement side to prevent cracking of or damage to the street pavement. The method used shall be such as not to weaken or damage the over burden. The pipe should not vary significantly either laterally or vertically from the intended straight line and grade. Any such variation shall be without any abrupt changes in direction. Any pipe damaged or misaligned shall be removed and replaced. The use of water and other fluids in connection with boring operation will be permitted only to the extent necessary to lubricate the cuttings. Jetting is not permitted. Any overcutting of the bore hole will be remedied by pressure grouting the entire length of the installation. 
(3)  Excavation and backfill associated with boring operations shall be conducted in conformance with section 13-23. 
(b)  Water lines. All street pavement must be bored. All water line of six (6) inch outside pipe barrel diameter or greater shall be encased. The casing must be installed by boring such that the borehole is not greater by two (2) inches than the outside barrel diameter of the casing. Any water line less than six (6) inches outside barrel diameter shall be bored such that the bore hole is not greater by two (2) inches than the outside diameter of the bell of the water pipe. If this requirement cannot be met, then pipe of barrel diameter less than six (6) inches must be encased. Pipes made of acceptable material that require no joints may be installed without casing. When pipes are encased, the casing shall extend across the street pavement from ditch line to ditch line or to not less than two (2) feet beyond back of curb. Pipes or casings shall not be less than forty-two (42) inches below the pavement surface not less than twenty-four (24) inches below the theoretical flow line of the side ditches. The crown of the borehole will be not less than forty-two (42) inches below the surface of the pavement. Taps into existing facilities under street pavement that exist at less than forty-two (42) inches below the pavement will be allowed. 
(c)  Gravity sewer lines. All street pavement must be bored. Gravity sewer lines shall be installed by boring method such that the diameter of the bore hole is not larger than the outside diameter of the gravity sewer pipe barrel (not flange) plus three (3) inches; if this requirement cannot be met, the sewer pipe must be encased. When pipes are encased, the casing shall extend across the street pavement from ditch line to ditch line or to not less than two (2) feet beyond back of curb. Pipes or casings shall not be less than forty-two (42) inches below the pavement surface nor less than twenty-four (24) inches below the theoretical flow line of the side ditches. The casing shall be installed by boring such that the borehole is not greater than two (2) inches than the outside barrel diameter of the casing. The crown of the borehole must be not less than forty-two (42) inches below the pavement surface unless it is required to tie into existing lines. 
(d)  Sewer force mains. All street pavement must be bored. Any sewer force mains of six (6) inch outside pipe barrel diameter or greater shall be encased. When pipes are encased, the casing shall extend across the street pavement from ditch line of ditch line or to not less than two (2) feet beyond back of curb. Pipes or casings shall be not less than forty-two (42) inches below the pavement surface nor less than twenty-four (24) inches below the theoretical flow line of the side ditches. Boring and casing requirements shall be the same as for water lines. 
(e)  Electrical. All street pavement must be bored. Boring and casing requirements shall be the same as for gravity sewer lines. 
(f)  Gas. All street pavement must be bored. Any six (6) inch outside pipe barrel diameter line or greater shall be encased. When pipes are encased, the casing shall extend across the street pavement from ditch line to ditch line or to not less than two (2) feet beyond back of curb. Pipes or casings shall be not less than forty-two (42) inches below the pavement surface nor less than twenty-four (24) inches below the theoretical flow line of the side ditches. The same requirements apply as for water lines except that any gas line operated under pressure greater than two hundred (200) pounds per square inch must be encased regardless of its diameter. 
(g)  Telephone and television cable. All street pavement must be bored. Boring and casing requirements shall be the same as for gravity sewer lines. 
(Ord. No. 1231, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-23. - Street excavation, backfill and restoration. 
    Removal of the street pavement and excavation below the street pavement will not be allowed except in extreme cases. The applicant for a permit requiring removal of and excavation below street pavement shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the inspector that an exception is warranted. This includes connections to existing facilities which lie beneath the street pavement. When street pavement is removed and excavated, the following requirements shall apply: 
(a)  General: 
(1)  Trenches shall be excavated at right angles to the roadway centerline or as near [to] right angles as possible. No existing drainage structures may be used for the purpose of pipe crossing. If a street pavement is cut, it will be done one travel lane at a time, thereby allowing traffic on the other lane; except that with proper justification and city approval, the entire pavement may be cut at one time. 
(2)  Ditches, banquettes, shoulders and/or planting spaces subject to trenching shall be replaced in the condition which existed prior to the excavation or better, particularly regarding sod or grass, and proper elevation of finished surface. All excess material shall be removed and well graded to assure no obstructions to mowing operation. In planting areas, no trench or excavation shall be made that will remove or endanger any shrubbery, flowers, trees or other planting, but should it be determined that a trench must be excavated at a location that would cause removal or endanger any planting, special arrangements shall be made with the city for said work and replacement or replanting of same prior to making excavations. 
(3)  When the permitted utility repair(s) or installation work and backfill is completed, the temporary pavement patching shall be completed and traffic restored that same day in accordance with subsection (c) hereinbelow. The temporary pavement restoration work shall then be completed before the beginning of construction on another section of the permittee's project. In any case, the permanent pavement restoration shall be completed no more than thirty (30) days (weather permitting) after traffic is first restored on the temporary pavement patching. 
(b)  Trenching and backfilling. Trenching and backfilling procedures shall be in accordance with sound engineering practices and following procedures: 
(1)  All excavations shall be shored and sheeted adjacent to pavement as required to prevent the trench wall from moving and damaging the pavement surface. 
(2)  It shall be duty and obligation of the permittee to barricade the excavation or cover the opening, as is necessary, to insure a safe working area in accordance with acceptable standards (MUTCD). The permittee shall hold harmless and indemnify the city from any and all claims, causes of action, lawsuits, damages to property, person or death, or as a result of such work by the permittee. 
(3)  All backfill for excavations below street pavement (includes that part of the trench within 2 (two) feet of pavement edges) shall consist of 610 grade limestone (compacted in 6 (six) inch to 8 (eight) inch lifts to ninety-five (95) per cent of standard proctor density) or flowable fill equivalent to "Filcrete" or backfill treated with a soil stabilizer equivalent to "Perma-Soil" or approved combination thereof. 
Flowable fill shall be cementitious grout mixture of sand, cement, and water in the following proportions: 
Ingredient Amount  Cement 188 lbs. Sand 3,010 lbs. Water 46.2 gals.  
The above mix design will produce one cubic yard of mixture and takes into consideration a five point seven (5.7) per cent moisture in the sand aggregate. Any alteration of this mix is not acceptable and must be removed at the permittee's expense. The contractor shall notify the city when ready for backfilling and the city inspector shall observe conditions prior to and during backfilling operations. 
Perma-Soil, or equal, shall be used in accordance with its manufacturer's instructions to increase the compressive strength to at least that of the limestone or flowable fill backfill method specified herein. 
(4)  Where soil backfill alone is required or preferred by the utility owner to be placed around the pipe for protective measures, it shall be selected "A-4" soil classification, as per the American Association of State Highway and Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development's classification system for soils, and shall be free of all foreign matter. Protective soil cover shall be limited to a maximum of six (6) inches above the top of the pipe. Soil that is dug out of the excavation may be used for backfill if it meets the aforementioned soil classification and is approved by the city. The backfill soil must be sufficiently pulverized and dry (or moist) in order to attain proper compaction. All soil backfill under the street pavement shall be mechanically tamped in six (6) inch layers to ninety-five (95) per cent of standard proctor density. In areas outside the street pavement, soil backfill shall be compacted in six (6) inch layers to ninety (90) per cent of standard proctor density. Sand backfill will not be used beneath any pavement or around any drainage structure unless requested in writing and approved in writing by a qualified representative of the city. Sufficient "end" plugs of acceptable soil material will be required to continue the sand backfill. 
(c)  Temporary pavement patching. All temporary pavement patching shall be accomplished in accordance with sound engineering practices and the following procedures: 
a.  Immediately upon completion of the utility repair or installation, limestone or flowable fill backfill will be brought up to match precisely the existing street surface as a temporary, but smooth-riding pavement patch and traffic shall be restored as soon as possible thereafter. 
b.  Permittee shall be responsible for maintaining this smooth-riding temporary pavement patch until the permanent patch is made. Permittee will respond immediately to any call by the city for repair of the temporary patch. 
(d)  Permanent concrete pavement restoration. All permanent concrete pavement restoration shall be accomplished in accordance with sound engineering practices and the following procedures: 
1.  A four thousand (4,000) psi (minimum) Portland Cement Concrete (PCC) pavement shall be used for street restoration and a two thousand five hundred (2,500) psi (minimum) PCC pavement shall be used for sidewalk and curb restoration. 
2.  The pavement shall be carefully cut to produce a straight, clean edge around the patch to be restored, with all corners square. The patch shall be a rectangle or square with its perimeter lines running parallel or perpendicular to the street centerline. 
3.  If a street pavement cut is made within two (2) feet of an existing crack or pavement joint, the cut shall be extended past the crack or to the joint. 
4.  If a street pavement cut is made near an existing curb and gutter, both the curb and gutter and the intermediate pavement shall be removed and restored in kind to prevent any subsequent destabilization of the existing curb and gutter structure. Any evidence of such destabilization resulting from the permittee's construction work shall, upon demand from the city, require permittee to immediately remove and replace all structures in kind at no cost to the city in accordance with sections 13-25 and 13-26 of this article. 
5.  All excavated material, loose material, debris, etc. shall be hauled out of the work area and disposed of by the permittee. 
6.  An epoxy-bonding agent is to be applied to the inside edge of the cut immediately before pouring concrete. The epoxy resin system to be used must be first approved by the city. Instead of the above mentioned epoxy-bonding agent, it will be acceptable to install steel dowels which will bind the new pavement to the old existing pavement and provide for load transfer. These dowels must be installed in a manner acceptable to the city. Any franchisee of the City of Crowley shall be exempt from the requirements of this paragraph, so long as permittee's finished street patches remain stable and in satisfactory condition. 
7.  Whenever Portland Cement Concrete is used in the street restoration process, the permittee shall submit to the city inspector documentation from the concrete supplier showing the concrete design mix and strength of the concrete actually delivered to the site of street restoration. 
8.  All concrete placement, vibration and form work and curing shall be in accordance with the 1992 edition (section 601) or the applicable section of the latest subsequent edition of the Louisiana Standard Specifications for Roads and Bridges. The finished texture shall be a "broom finish". 
9.  Traffic [may] not resume on the newly restored pavement until a compressive strength of three thousand (3,000) psi is attained in the concrete at the patch. The permittee shall provide for effective traffic control and maintenance during the concrete curing period in accordance with acceptable standards (MUTCD).
