At any time after the patch is completed, any evidence of failure of a patch shall be met with a demand from the city in that it be immediately removed and replaced in kind at no cost to the city in accordance with sections 13-25 and 13-26 of this article. 
10.  If the restoration encompasses a contraction or expansion joint, the permittee shall replace it. The new joint shall match the original design and be of the same quality or better. 
11.  Minimum patch width shall be four (4) feet wide. 
12.  The existing concrete pavement shall be cut back a minimum of twelve (12) inches past the vertical trench wall, allowing the newly restored pavement to be supported on the existing road base and/or undisturbed earth. 
13.  The minimum thickness of restored pavement shall be the thickness of the existing pavement or ten (10) inches whichever is greater. 
(e)  Permanent asphaltic concrete pavement restoration. All permanent asphaltic concrete pavement restoration shall be accomplished in accordance with sound engineering practices and the following procedures: 
1.  The pavement shall be saw cut to produce a straight, clean edge around the patch to be restored with all corners square. Minimum patch width shall be six (6) feet. The patch shall be a rectangle or square with its perimeter lines running parallel or perpendicular to the street centerline. 
2.  Full-depth asphaltic concrete shall be compacted from the subgrade layer to the finished pavement grade in layers not to exceed three (3) inches in thickness. 
3.  Full-depth asphaltic concrete shall be a minimum thickness of eight (8) inches below the existing asphalt pavement surface or to the bottom of the existing base, whichever is greater. 
4.  All asphaltic concrete materials, tack, coat, etc. shall conform to the above mentioned latest version of specifications of the Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development. 
5.  Prior to compacting asphaltic concrete within the trench or restoration of the pavement, a tack coat shall be applied to the top and the inside edge of the existing cut asphaltic concrete pavement once it is swept clean. 
6.  Compaction of the asphaltic concrete shall be obtained by mechanical tampers or rollers that will adequately compact the asphaltic concrete in all areas of the trench. The compaction tools must be approved by the city. 
7.  When the final layer of asphalt is laid down to be compacted, it shall be a thickness of twenty (20) per cent more than the desired compacted thickness. This will compact flush with the plane of the existing pavement. Example: If desired thickness is two and one-half (21/2) inches, lay down three (3) inches, since 2.5 × 0.2 = 0.5?, and 0.5? + 2.5? = 3.0?. 
8.  The finished asphalt shall be "finished rolled" until all creases are removed from the new pavement. 
9.  The newly restored asphalt shall be protected by means of a flagman or some effective barrier to prevent traffic from driving on the patch until it has sufficiently cooled. 
10.  On all streets having asphaltic concrete surfacing on a PCC pavement, a composite patch shall be required (see Exhibit D [on file in the city clerk's office]). The existing concrete pavements shall be cut back a minimum of twelve (12) inches past the vertical trench wall, allowing the newly restored pavement to be supported on the existing road base and/or undisturbed earth. A two-inch thick space shall be left between the PCC patch and the top of the existing asphaltic concrete surface, to provide for the correct restoration of the new asphaltic concrete pavement, the same requirements for concrete pavement restoration and asphaltic concrete pavement restoration mentioned previously apply here. Traffic should not resume on the newly restored base and asphalt pavement until the concrete base reaches a compressive strength of three thousand (3,000) psi, see subsection (d)9. 
11.  As an alternative to either the full depth asphaltic concrete or the composite pavement restoration requirements outlined above, a twelve-inch thick, black-pigmented PCC permanent patch (i.e., colored a shade of black to match that of the existing pavement) will be allowed. This alternate will be subject to all the requirements of subsection (d) herein. 
12.  On all asphalt surfaced streets, except those that have full-depth asphalt bases, a PCC base may be used instead of a full-depth asphalt. The concrete base shall be a minimum four thousand (4,000) psi, and shall be placed over the compacted subgrade and shall have a minimum thickness of eight (8) inches or to the bottom of the existing base, whichever thickness is greater. A two-inch thick space shall be left between the restored base and the top of the existing asphaltic concrete surface, to provide for the correct restoration of the new asphaltic concrete pavement. The same requirements for concrete mentioned previously apply here. Traffic should not resume on the newly restored base and asphalt pavement until the concrete base reaches a compressive strength of three thousand (3,000) (psi see subsection (d)9. 
(f)  Franchisee's compliance and revocation of exemption. If, at anytime, the city engineer and the street commissioner shall certify to the mayor and board of aldermen that the operations and activities of a franchisee or its subcontractor shall have caused damage to the city streets, the franchisee shall comply with all provisions of this article. The franchisee shall have ten (10) days in which to appeal the decertification to the mayor and board of aldermen. The mayor and board of aldermen shall have the ability to recertify the franchisee for the exemption and/or may permanently disqualify the franchisee from any further exemption from the requirements of this article as occasion may require. 
(Ord. No. 1231, § 1, 4-11-2000; Ord. No. 1234, §§ 2, 3, 4, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-24. - Inspection. 
    The city may assign an inspector to the work site on a periodic basis to observe the workmanship and quality of materials being used in the restoration work. The inspector shall act only as an observer in the permittee's effort to accomplish the results as outlined herein. The presence of an inspector does not relieve the permittee of the obligation to fully comply with the intent of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1231, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-25. - Unacceptable work. 
(a)  Should any person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities fail to replace materials, fail to restore areas at least to their original conditions, or in any way fail to comply with conditions of these regulations, the city shall notify the permittee, in writing, to be delivered either by certified mail, return receipt requested or by hand delivery to the permittee's designated representative on the application of the permit, that such work is unacceptable or fails to meet or comply with these regulations, a description thereof and shall inform the permittee of the necessary work or restoration required, which work shall be completed within a reasonable time. 
(b)  Should any permittee, person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities fail to begin to perform necessary work for restoration to original condition or comply with these regulations after ten (10) days of receipt of said notice, the city shall have the right to perform all necessary work to comply with the regulations and/or prompt restore the are to original condition. Upon completion of all necessary work by the city, the city shall invoice the permittee, person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities responsible for said work, for the actual cost of construction and engineering, plus twenty-five (25) per cent administrative charge. In the event that said invoice is not paid in full within thirty (30) days of date of receipt thereof, the city shall have the right to enforce collection of same together with reasonable attorney fees and all court costs in connection with prosecuting the claim in any court of proper jurisdiction. 
(c)  The city shall have the right to revoke a permit upon any violation by the permittee of these regulations. The city shall have the right to refuse to grant permit to a person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities who has, in the past, failed to comply with all the requirements of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1231, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-26. - Failure to work: warranty. 
(a)  Should settlement occur over the restored borings, trenches or excavations or should there occur any other failure due to faulty construction within a period of one year after restoration is completed, it shall be the obligation of the permittee to correct said settlement and/or failure including refilling, tamping and repaving, re-sodding and re-seeding. 
(b)  The city shall notify, by certified mail or by personal delivery, the permittee of any condition due to settlement and/or any other failure of restoration. The permittee shall have ten (10) days after receipt of said notice to make the necessary corrections, including the opening, refilling, tamping and repaving, re-sodding and re-seeding as may be required by the city. 
(c)  In the event the permittee fails to respond to the proper notice as set forth above, the city shall have the right to perform the necessary corrective work. In the event the city performs the necessary corrective work, the permittee shall be obligated to pay the city the actual cost to the city plus as twenty-five (25) per cent administrative charge. After the city has performed the necessary corrective work, the city shall invoice the said permittee for the actual cost plus a twenty-five (25) per cent administrative charge. In the event that said invoice is not paid in full within thirty (30) days of date of receipt thereof, the city shall have the right to enforce collection of same together with reasonable attorney fees and all court costs in connection with prosecuting the claim in any court of proper jurisdiction. 
(d)  The city shall have the right to revoke a permit upon any violation by the permittee of these regulations. The city shall have the right to refuse to grant permit to a person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities who has, in the past, failed to comply with all the requirements of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1231, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-27. - Compliance with specifications required. 
    It shall be the duty of the permittee to do all work in strict accordance with the specifications, terms, and conditions set out in his application, permit and these regulations. Any failure to comply therewith shall be punishable in accordance with the applicable conditions of the city Code. In addition thereto, the permittee shall be liable to the city for any cost, expense or liability incurred by the city by reason of the failure of the permittee to strictly comply with the specifications, terms and conditions. 
(Ord. No. 1231, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Secs. 13-28, 13-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - INSTALLATION OF CULVERTS, STORM DRAINS, DRIVEWAYS AND WALKWAYS WITHIN PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY AND STREETS 

Sec. 13-30. - Permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities, private or public, to install, construct, remove or replace culverts, pipes, storm drains, driveways, walkways or any other structure which may affect drainage within the public right-of-way of any street, alley, shoulder, sidewalk, banquette, median, boulevard, curb or gutter, ditch or planting space located within public right-of-way in the City of Crowley, hereinafter "street", without first obtaining a permit from the City of Crowley. 
(b)  Hereinafter, the word "city" shall mean the corporate boundary of the city in the context of location, and shall mean the mayor, inspector or duly authorized representative in the context of person. 
(c)  No permit shall be required when any person has been awarded a public contract, pursuant to the laws of the State of Louisiana, for the construction of improvements on behalf of the city. The City of Crowley shall not be required to obtain a permit for work to be performed, but all city work shall adhere to construction specifications contained herein. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-31. - Application for permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to install, construct, remove or replace culverts, pipes, storm drains, driveways, walkways or any other structure which may affect drainage within the public right-of-way of any street, alley, shoulder, sidewalk, banquette, median, boulevard, curb or gutter, ditch or planting space located within public right-of-way in the city shall make written application for a permit on forms provided for said purpose in the office of the city inspector. 
(b)  The applicant shall provide full name, address and telephone number, the exact location of the proposed work or description of the proposed work, the purpose of the proposed work and a schematic diagram shall be drawn as near to scale as possible and shall submit sufficient data, plans, specifications or drawings which shall clearly define the proposed work and the plans for street right-of-way restoration. 
(c)  The permit shall be secured prior to the commencement of all work. 
(d)  Any work or excavation within the public rights-of-way which is conducted without a permit shall be stopped and no further work shall be allowed to recommence until the proper permit has been issued for said work. 
(e)  It shall be the obligation of all applicants to make investigations necessary to locate all underground utilities, structures, pipelines, pipelines and conduits in the area in which work is contemplated. 
(f)  The permittee shall maintain and protect any and all existing structures and utilities within the limits of the work area or as reasonably near thereto. 
(g)  The City of Crowley shall determine whether such plans and drawings are sufficient and requiring existing detail of other utility locations and the opinion of the work to justify such a requirement. 
(h)  No deposit shall be required for a permit to perform work within city right-of-way. However, the permittee is fully responsible to restore the work area to a condition as good or better than the original condition. 
(i)  It shall be the duty and obligation of the permittee to safeguard the public by maintaining the necessary guards, barricades and safety lights, etc., in accordance with law and the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, latest edition, hereinafter MUTCD. The permittee shall maintain the street in a good and safe condition. The permittee shall hold harmless and indemnify the city from any and all claims, causes of action, lawsuits, damages to property, person or death, or as a result of such work by the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-32. - Pipe size, alignment, elevations and slopes. 
(a)  Prior to installation, proper pipe sizes, elevations and slopes shall typically be determined and set by the city. All pipe sizes shall be approved by the inspector. No pipes shall be smaller than the largest of the two (2) nearest (one upstream, one downstream of the proposed pipe) street crossing pipes. However, in any case, no pipes shall be smaller than fifteen (15) inches inside diameter. Vertical control of the invert of the pipe and offsets from the centerline of the pipe should be computed and recorded on a cut sheet for installing the pipe, as directed by the inspector. 
(b)  The permit must be applied for at least one week prior to the anticipated date of installation to allow sufficient time to determine compliance with all requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-33. - Material selection. 
(a)  Continuous subsurface storm drains, major drainage structures, flumes and other systems which are required to be watertight (Type 3 joints), shall be constructed of the following materials, to-wit: 
(1)  Reinforced concrete pipe (RCP). 
(2)  Reinforced concrete pipe arch (RCPA). 
(3)  Ribbed polyvinyl chloride culvert pipe (RPVCCP). 
(b)  Other subsurface storm drains (Type 2 joints) including street cross drains and side drains for driveways and non-continuous ditches may use the following materials, to-wit: 
(1)  Bituminous coated corrugated steel pipe (BCCSP). 
(2)  Bituminous coated corrugated steel pipe arch (BCCSPA). 
(3)  Reinforced concrete pipe (RCP). 
(4)  Reinforced concrete pipe arch (RCPA). 
(5)  Ribbed polyvinyl chloride culvert pipe (RPVCCP). 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-34. - Allowable materials. 
(a)  Reinforced concrete pipe. 
(1)  Reinforced concrete pipe shall conform to the requirements of ASTM designation: C76 for Class III Wall B. Circular reinforcement rather than elliptical reinforcement shall be used in all concrete pipe. 
(2)  Nonreinforced concrete pipe shall not be allowed under any circumstances. 
(b)  Corrugated steel pipe and pipe arch. Corrugated steel pipe and pipe arch shall conform to the requirements of Type I (culvert pipes, circular section) and TYPE II (culvert pipes, other than circular section) of AASHTO designation: M36 amended as follows: 
(1)  Helical pipe to be joined shall have either helical or annular ends and joining shall be made with approved coupling bands. Pipe with annular ends shall have the exposed ends of seams spot welded. 
(2)  The minimum sheet thickness, or gage, shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations based on fill height and LDOTD standards for same. 
(3)  For smooth lined pipe, the inside circumference of the pipe shall be fully lined with bituminous material in accordance with AASHTO designation: M190 Type D. 
(4)  For paved invert pipe, the invert shall be paved with bituminous material conforming to AASHTO designation: M190 Type C. 
(c)  Bituminous coated corrugated steel pipe and pipe arch. Bituminous coated corrugated steel pipe and pipe arch shall conform to AASHTO designation: M190, amended as follows: 
(1)  AASHTO designation: M36 is amended in accordance with subsection (c) hereinabove. 
(2)  The coating shall be Type A, fully bituminous coated unless otherwise specified. 
(d)  Asbestos bonded corrugated steel pipe and pipe arch. 
(1)  Asbestos bonded corrugated steel pipe and pipe arch shall be fabricated from asbestos bonded sheets. The base metal and the fabrication of pipes and connecting bands shall conform to subsection (c) hereinabove. The steel sheets shall be coated on both sides with a layer of asbestos fibers applied by pressing a sheet of asbestos fiber into the molten metallic bonding medium. Immediately after the metallic has solidified, the asbestos fibers shall be thoroughly impregnated with a bituminous saturant. The finished sheets shall be of the first-class commercial quality, free from blisters and unsaturated spots. 
(2)  After fabrication, the asbestos bonded pipe and pipe arch shall be fully bituminous coated with a Type A coating in accordance with AASHTO designation: M190. Smooth lined and paved invert pipe shall be coated in accordance with subsection (c) hereinabove. 
(3)  The helical fabrication process is not allowed for asbestos bonded corrugated steel pipe and pipe arch. 
(e)  Corrugated aluminum pipe and pipe arch. Corrugated aluminum pipe and pipe arch shall conform to AASHTO designation: M 196, except helical pipe to be joined shall have either helical or annular ends, and joining shall be made with approved coupling bands. Pipe and annular ends shall have the exposed ends of seams spot welded. 
(f)  Corrugated aluminized steel pipe and pipe arch. Corrugated aluminized steel pipe shall conform to the following: 
(1)  Corrugated aluminized steel pipe shall be fabricated with sheet material conforming to AASHTO designation: M274-80I. 
(2)  Aluminized steel pipe shall be furnished either as circular or as a pipe-arch, and shall be fabricated with helical or annular corrugations. 
(3)  Corrugated aluminized steel pipe shall be joined with approved coupling bands. 
(4)  Corrugated aluminized steel pipe fabrication shall conform to the current AASHTO M36 specifications for corrugated steel pipe, amended in accordance with subsection (c) hereinabove. 
(g)  Structural plate pipe and pipe arch. Structural plate pipe and pipe arch shall conform to AASHTO designation: M167. Aluminum alloy structural plate pipe and pipe arch shall conform to AASHTO designation: M219. 
(h)  Plastic pipe. Plastic pipe may be of any of the following material types or products listed below. Joints shall be bell and spigot type with rubber gaskets conforming to ASTM F 477. Perforations, if approved, shall conform to AASHTO M 252. 
(1)  Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipe. 
a.  Smooth wall PVC pipe: Pipe fifteen (15) inch diameter shall conform to ASTM D 3034; pipe larger than fifteen (15) inches shall conform to ASTM F 679, T-1 Wall. 
b.  Ribbed PVC pipe: Pipe shall conform to ASTM F 794, Series 46, and shall have a minimum cell classification of 12454-C as defined in ASTM D 1784. 
c.  Profile wall PVC pipe: Pipe shall conform to ASTM F 949 and shall have a minimum cell classification of 12454-C as defined in ASTM D 1784. 
(2)  Polyethylene (PE) pipe. 
a.  Corrugated PE pipe: Pipe shall conform to AASHTO M 294, Type S, and shall have a minimum cell classification of 315412C as defined in ASTM D 3350. 
b.  Profile wall PE pipe: Pipe shall conform to ASTM F 894, RSC 160, and shall have a minimum cell classification of 334433C as defined in ASTM D 3350. 
(i)  Joint materials. Joint materials for pipe shall conform to the following: 
(1)  Rubber gaskets. Rubber Gaskets for pipe joints shall conform to AASHTO designation: M198, Type A. Each pipe manufacturer or supplier shall be capable of furnishing certificates of analysis certifying that gaskets conform to the above specifications. 
(2)  Flexible plastic gaskets. Flexible plastic gaskets for pipe joints shall conform to AASHTO designation: M198, Type B. 
(j)  Metal pipe gage. Metal pipe shall have a minimum sheet thickness (gage) as required by the manufacturer based on fill height and LDOTD standards. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-35. - Trenching and bedding. 
(a)  All trenches shall be excavated so that the walls are as nearly vertical as possible and to a minimum width which will provide working room to obtain specified compaction. Where required to safeguard construction workers or adjacent structures the sides of the trench shall be properly sheathed and braced. Where in the opinion of the inspector damage may result from withdrawing the sheathing, the sheathing will be required to be left in place. Proper cuts into the trench bottom shall be made at each bell to distribute the load to the barrel of the pipe. 
(b)  Any water accumulated in the trenches shall be removed prior to laying the pipe. During excavation, material suitable for backfilling shall be stockpiled in an orderly manner, a sufficient distance from the edge of the excavation to avoid overloading and to prevent slides or cave-in. 
(c)  For plastic pipe, bedding material shall be placed up to twelve (12) inches above pipe, street crossings and pipe under or within five (5) feet of pavement. 
(d)  Bedding material shall be placed up to the top of the pipe for side drains. 
(e)  If unstable material is encountered at the trench bottom, unstable material shall be excavated as necessary for complete removal and replaced with bedding material. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-36. - Setting or laying pipe. 
    When lines and grades are established by the city, all pipe shall be carefully laid to the lines and grades established by the city. Any pipe which is not true in alignment or which shows settlement after laying, shall be removed and relaid. The interior of all pipe shall be kept clear of debris as the work progresses. All tongue and groove joints shall be laid with the groove upgrade. All lifting holes in concrete pipe shall be sealed with precast concrete plugs, and joint material conforming to section 13-24(i) shall be used to make the seal water tight. 
Sec. 13-37. - Pipe joints. 
(a)  Concrete pipe. 
(1)  Concrete pipe shall have joints conforming to AASHTO designation: M198 and shall be joined with gasket material conforming to section 13-24(i). The procedure used in installing the gasket material shall be as recommended by the gasket manufacturer. 
(2)  The method of joining concrete pipe sections shall be such that the ends are fully entered and the inner surfaces are reasonably flush and even. An approved mechanical pipe puller shall be used for joining pipes for pipes greater than forty-two (42) inches I.D. All joint material protruding from the inside of the pipe shall be neatly trimmed to conform with the inside walls of the pipe. 
(3)  Type III joints having flexible plastic gasket only, shall be wrapped with plastic filter cloth for a minimum of twelve (12) inches on each side of the joint. Ends of the cloth shall be lapped at least ten (10) inches and edges of cloth shall be suitably secured. 
(4)  Fabric shall be a pervious sheet of plastic yarn. Plastic yarn shall consist of a long-chain synthetic polymer composed of at least eighty-five (85) per cent by weight of propylene or ethylene fabric and shall be constructed so that yarns will retain their relative position with respect to each other. Edges of fabric shall be finished to prevent the outer yarn from pulling away from the fabric. The fabric shall be an approved product from the LDOTD Qualified Products List. The fabric shall conform to the following requirements: 
Weight, oz./sq.yd., min. ASTM D1 910 3.0 Test Method EOS. (U.S. Sieve) LDOTD TR 630 50+ Test Method Aug. Grab Tensile lbs./in. min. ASTM D1 682 90 Test Method Grab Tensile (Any direction) ASTM D1 682 lbs./in. min. 75 Test Method Permeability Factor cm./sec., min. Method LDOTD TR 631 8 Test  
    The fabric shall be secured on each end section of each pipe by means of a noncorroding plastic strapping having a minimum breaking strength of three hundred eighty (380) pounds and securing the ends with a self-sealing buckle. Prior approval of this product by the city will be required before installation. 
(b)  Metal pipe. 
(1)  Metal pipe shall be joined by coupling bands conforming to subsection 13-24(i). Bands shall be fabricated from corrugated metal sheets of the same material as the pipe and shall have the same coating as used on the pipe. The thickness of the band may be two (2) standard sheet thicknesses lighter than the pipe, but not less than 0.064 inch thick nor more than 0.109 inch thick. Bands shall lap an equal distance on each of the pipe sections to be joined and shall be sealed with gasket material conforming to subsection 13-24(i). The gasket material shall be placed in two (2) corrugation recesses on each side of the pipe connection and overlapped in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions. 
(2)  Connecting bands shall consist of a single piece corrugated band with the same corrugations as the pipe. The bands shall be drawn tight by either one bolting through angles or using one-half inch galvanized steel rod and lugs with a minimum of four (4) rods used. Smooth stab-type bands and dimple bands will not be allowed for metal pipe and helically corrugated bands will not be allowed on pipe arch. 
(3)  Connecting bands shall be twelve (12) inches wide for pipe less than thirty-six (36) inches in diameter or pipe arch up to thirty-six (36) inch by twenty (22) inch; and twenty-four (24) inches wide for culverts thirty-six (36) in diameter and greater or for forty-three (43) inch by twenty-seven (27) inch pipe arch and greater. 
(c)  Plastic pipe. Bell and spigot joints: Gaskets shall be rubber O-rings. Just before jointing, O-ring and gasket seat shall be cleaned of dirt and other foreign material and coated with a flax soap lubricant. Pipe sizes less than forty-eight (48) inches may be joined by any method which fully seats joints without damaging pipe; larger pipe sizes shall be joined with a mechanical puller. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-38. - Backfilling. 
(a)  Upon completion and approval of the joints by the city inspector, backfill material, free from large clumps, rocks, or other hard substances shall be deposited evenly on both sides of the pipe in layers not exceeding eight (8) inches thick. Each layer shall be compacted by use of approved mechanical tampers to ninety-five (95) per cent of maximum density. Maximum density and in-place density shall be determined in accordance with LDOTD Designations: TR 418 and TR 401, respectively. Backfilling shall proceed in this manner to a point twelve (12) inches above the top of the pipe. Backfilling around the pipe shall avoid displacement of or damage to the pipe. All backfill material shall be approved before placement. 
(b)  The remainder of the backfill over and above twelve (12) inches above the surface of the pipe shall be thoroughly compacted to a minimum of ninety (90) per cent of maximum density at optimum moisture, except as provided below street or structural surfaces. No damage shall occur during compaction. Backfill material shall contain no stumps or roots and shall be free of lumber, trash, or other debris. The method of compaction shall be approved by the city. 
(c)  On surfaced streets or areas designated by the city, backfilling from a point twelve (12) inches above the top of the pipe to street grade shall be accomplished by depositing the backfill material in layers not exceeding eight (8) inches in thickness and tamping each layer with approved mechanical tampers to a density of ninety-five (95) per cent of maximum density in accordance with the requirements designated in the previous paragraph. This requirement shall apply for the width of the roadway plus five (5) feet on each side unless otherwise approved. If necessary, compaction shall be verified through compaction tests ordered by the city. In the event the material excavated during the trenching operation has a high moisture content, this material shall be dried to optimum moisture by blading and disking or other suitable methods prior to backfilling. If unsuitable material for backfilling is encountered in a given location, suitable material obtained from offsite or other locations shall be used in the backfill operation. 
(d)  Backfill for all plastic drainage pipe shall be granular material or flowable fill in accordance with section 13-23 regarding excavations and construction activities within public rights-of-way in the City of Crowley. Installed pipe that has deformed beyond acceptable limits shall be removed and replaced or relaid using better procedures. Relaying will be permitted only if the pipe returns to the proper shape upon removal and no other damage or cracks are evident. The minimum cover for all plastic pipe shall be twelve (12) inches. 
(e)  In lieu of the previously described method of obtaining suitable backfill material, backfill with granular material or flowable fill conforming to the above requirements for plastic pipe shall be allowed. All granular material shall be compacted to the same density described previously in this paragraph. If part of the trench lies in an area designated to be surfaced and paralleling the centerline of the roadway the total width of the trench shall be compacted as designated in this paragraph. 
(f)  It is expressly understood that all easements and rights-of-way shall be restored to a condition equal to its original condition or better, and in a condition satisfactory to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-39. - Flushing drainage lines. 
    If storm drainage lines are found to contain sand, gravel or other foreign matter when inspected by the city they shall be flushed with a sufficient volume of water to remove all foreign matter prior to final acceptance. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-40. - Maintenance of traffic. 
(a)  Pipe installation operations shall be conducted in such a manner so that interference with public travel will be minimized. Suitable bridges, detours or other temporary facilities for the accommodation of public or private travel may be required, as directed by the city. Maintenance of traffic may be curtailed providing that permission is obtained from the owners or tenants of private property or proper public authority, or both, to obstruct traffic within the said limits and time agreed upon. 
(b)  The city police and local fire protection authorities shall be kept informed at all times of the location of construction operations and potential conflict with fire lanes and shall maintain access for firefighting equipment as requested by the fire department. 
(c)  One-way traffic shall be maintained on all streets during construction, except where suitable detours or other arrangements are agreed to. All barricades, warning signs, lights, temporary signals and other protective devices to be utilized in the maintenance of traffic shall conform with the Louisiana Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD). 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-41. - Care of streets, sidewalks and roads. 
(a)  All excess materials, debris or other obstructions shall be removed from the streets or roads immediately after the backfilling has been completed. No cross streets, sidewalks or roads shall be wholly obstructed, except by special permission from the city. 
(b)  Streets, sidewalks, roads and culverts shall be repaired or replaced in accordance with section 13-23 regarding excavation and construction activities within public rights-of-way of the City of Crowley. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-42. - Barricades. 
    Barricades shall be provided at locations where there exists an open hole or trench or trenches that have not had sufficient settlement to withstand traffic loads. All such barricades shall be properly lighted at night with electric or oil flares, and shall conform with the MUTCD. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-43. - Protection of public or private property and easements. 
(a)  All underground and above ground utilities shall be continuously maintained and protected, including the restoration of all public utilities, including water mains, water services, gas mains, gas services, culverts, drains, ditches, curbs, sidewalks, landscaping and/or other facilities which may be damaged, to a condition at least equal to their original status. All water mains and services shall be repaired within six (6) hours. 
(b)  All work shall be accomplished so as to cause the least amount of disturbance and a minimum amount of damage. Trenches shall not be left open during weekends or holidays, and trenches shall not be left open for more than forty-eight (48) hours. 
(c)  Where required by the city, the top soil shall be stripped from the trench or construction area and stock-piled in such a manner that it may be replaced, upon completion of construction. Ornamental trees and shrubbery shall be carefully removed, with the earth surrounding their roots wrapped in burlap and replanted in their original positions within forty-eight (48) hours. All shrubbery or trees destroyed, or damaged, shall be replaced with material of equal quality. In the event that it is necessary to trench through any lawn areas, the sod shall be carefully cut and rolled and replaced after the trenches have been backfilled, the backfilling and compacting to be as described for surfaced areas. The lawn area shall then be cleaned, by sweeping or other means, of all earth and debris. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-44. - Excess material. 
    Material excavated during the trenching operation, that is not used for backfilling the pipe, shall be promptly hauled off. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-45. - Qualified products. 
    The LDOTD qualified products list may be referred to for the approval of specific products proposed for all work under these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-46. - Regulations regarding excavations and construction activities within public rights of way in the city of crowley. 
    All work and construction performed under this article shall adhere to the provisions of article II of this chapter insofar as they apply to excavation and construction activities within public rights of way for protection of the street pavement and surfaces. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-47. - Inspection. 
    The city may inspect the work site on a periodic basis to observe the workmanship and quality of materials being used in the restoration work. The inspector shall act only as an observer in the permittee's effort to accomplish the results as outlined herein. The presence of an inspector does not relieve the permittee of the obligation to fully comply with the intent of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-48. - Unacceptable work. 
(a)  Should any person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities fail to replace materials, fail to restore areas at least to their original conditions, or in any way fail to comply with conditions of these regulations, the city shall notify the permittee, in writing, to be delivered either by certified mail, return receipt requested or by hand delivery to the permittee's designated representative on the application of the permit, that such work is unacceptable or fails to meet or comply with these regulations, a description thereof and shall inform the permittee of the necessary work or restoration required, which work shall be completed within a reasonable time. 
(b)  Should any permittee, person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities fail to begin to perform necessary work for restoration to original condition or comply with these regulations after ten (10) days of receipt of said notice, the city shall have the right to perform all necessary work to comply with the regulations and/or prompt restore the are to original condition. Upon completion of all necessary work by the city, the city shall invoice the permittee, person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities responsible for said work, for the actual cost of construction and engineering, plus twenty-five (25) per cent administrative charge. In the event that said invoice is not paid in full within thirty (30) days of date of receipt thereof, the city shall have the right to enforce collection of same together with reasonable attorney fees and all court costs in connection with prosecuting the claim in any court of proper jurisdiction. 
(c)  The city shall have the right to revoke a permit upon any violation by the permittee of these regulations. The city shall have the right to refuse to grant permit to a person, firm, corporation or owner of utilities who has, in the past, failed to comply with all the requirements of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-2000) 
Sec. 13-49. - Failure of work; warranty. 
(a)  Should there occur any failure due to faulty materials or construction within a period of one year after installation is completed, it shall be the obligation of the permittee to correct said failure including re-installing, re-backfilling, re-tamping, re-paving, re-sodding and re-seeding. 
(b)  The city shall notify the permittee, by certified mail or by personal delivery, of any failure of corrective work or restoration. The permittee shall have ten (10) days after receipt of said notice to make the necessary corrections, including the re-installing, re-backfilling, re-tamping and re-paving, re-sodding and re-seeding as may be required by the city. 
(c)  In the event the permittee fails to respond to the proper notice as set forth above, the city shall have the right to perform the necessary corrective work. In the event the city performs the necessary corrective work, the permittee shall be obligated to pay the city the actual cost to the city plus a twenty-five (25) per cent administrative charge. After the city has performed the necessary corrective work, the city shall invoice the said permittee for the actual cost plus a twenty-five (25) per cent administrative charge and the said permittee shall have ten (10) days in which to pay the invoice in full. In the event the said permittee fails to pay the invoice in full within the said ten (10) days, the city shall have the right to enforce collection of said actual cost, plus twenty-five (25) administrative charge plus all cost of prosecuting the suit in any court of proper jurisdiction. 
(d)  In addition thereto, the City of Crowley shall have the right to revoke a permit upon any violation by the permittee of these regulations, and shall have the right to refuse a future permit to a person, firm, or corporation who has, in the past, failed to comply with all the requirements of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-00) 
Sec. 13-50. - Compliance with specifications required. 
    It shall be the duty of the permittee to perform all work in strict accordance with the specifications, terms, and conditions set out in his application, permit and these regulations. Any failure to comply therewith shall be punishable in accordance with the applicable conditions of the city Code. In addition thereto, the permittee shall he liable to the city for any cost, expense or liability incurred by the city by reason of the failure of the permittee to strictly comply with the specifications, terms and conditions. 
(Ord. No. 1230, § 1, 4-11-00) 
Secs. 13-51-13-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ordinance No. 1314, adopted March 8, 2005, enacted provisions to be designated as §§ 13-50-13-58. In as much as there already exists § 13-50, said provisions have been redesignated as §§ 13-60-13-68. Original numbering can be found in history notes at the end of each section. 

Sec. 13-60. - General. 
    Prior to preparation of a geometric division of land, it is suggested that the developer contact the zoning and planning administrator to obtain a copy of subdivision regulations. The developer should thoroughly familiarize himself with these regulations and with the proposals of the master plan as they pertain to the tract of land being considered for development. 
    The sale of lots, a plat, or tract that has not been approved by the city planning commission and/or the city council is strictly forbidden. 
(Ord. No. 1314, § 1(13-50), 3-8-05) 
Sec. 13-61. - Jurisdiction. 
    The city planning commission of Crowley has jurisdiction over all subdivisions, existing and proposed in the city limits. Prior to the sale of any lot from a plat, the proposed plat for the subdivision must be submitted to the planning commission for review. Written approval will be issued prior to recordation with the clerk of courts of the sale of any lot. If the plat is disapproved, the planning commission will issue written reasons for disapproval. 
    Public monies will not be spent for any reason in subdivisions that have not met the requirements established by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 1314, § 1(13-51), 3-8-05) 
Sec. 13-62. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of these regulations, certain words and phrases used herein are defined as follows: 
    A.A.S.H.T.O. means the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials. 
    Alley means a minor public right-of-way used primarily for vehicular access to the rear or side of properties otherwise abutting on the street. 
    Arterial street means a street designated to handle the volume of traffic created by major traffic generators with emphasis on thru movement. 
    City means the City of Crowley, being in Acadia Parish, State of Louisiana. 
    City council means the chief legislative body of the City of Crowley. 
    Collector street means a street that provides transition from minor streets to major streets, including the principal and circulation streets of a residential development. 
    Commission or Planning commission shall refer to the body of the city planning commission of Crowley, Louisiana. 
    Comprehensive plan means the reports, maps, charts and other descriptive material in the comprehensive plan for the planning area made and adopted by the planning commission. 
    Conceptual plan means a preliminary plan of an undeveloped tract of land showing general land use, thoroughfares and primary natural or man-made characteristics of the site. 
    Construction plan means plans and specifications for the construction of on- and off-site improvements for a tract of land as prepared by a civil engineer registered within the state. 
    Crosswalk means a public right-of-way utilized primarily for pedestrian access along, through or across a block or any portion thereof. 
    Cul-de-sac means a public right-of-way, characteristically short with a vehicular turnaround at the end. 
    Designated review agent (DRA) means an individual appointed by the mayor to review and approve or disapprove subdivision plats, construction plans and other matters that may be pertinent to the development and/or resubdivision of subdivisions. 
    Double frontage means a lot with access to two (2) parallel streets. 
    Easement means a grant by a property owner of the use, for a specific purpose or purposes of a designated strip of land to the general public, a corporation or other individuals. 
    Industrial subdivision means a subdivision of land with a primary function serving industrial or wholesale development. 
    Limited access highway means a street to which access is prohibited except at specific points. 
    Lot, tract, or plat means a unit or area of land for transfer of ownership or development or both. 
    Major street means a street designed to handle fast moving or heavy traffic. 
    Major thoroughfare plan means a plan which delineates a system of streets adopted by the planning commission. 
    Marginal access street (frontage road) means a street which is parallel to and adjacent to a major street, and which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. 
    Minor street means a street that is used primarily for access to abutting residential properties. Mobile home park means an area of land to serve mobile homes, with no transfer of title. 
    Mobile home subdivision means a subdivision of land serving mobile homes where title is to be transferred. 
    Official map means a map showing existing and established streets and additions resulting from approval of subdivision plats and the subsequent recording of such approved plats. 
    Planning area means the area under the jurisdiction of the planning commission. 
    Plat means the metes and bounds description of the boundary survey and interior lot and block dimensions of the subdivision prepared by a land surveyor registered in the state. 
    Preliminary plat means a plat that depicts the geometric layout of a subdivision with all proposed street, lots and easements drawn to scale. 
    Protective covenant means a restriction on the use of private property within a subdivision for the purpose of providing mutual protection against undesirable aspects of development. Protective covenants regulating the use of land represent an express agreement between the subdivider and the lot purchasers. 
    Public improvements means any of the following: roadway pavement, curbs, gutters, sidewalks, crosswalks, water and sanitary sewage systems, storm sewers, electric power and gas lines, street lighting systems and other appurtenant construction as related to the subdivision preliminary plan. 
    Residential subdivision means a subdivision constructed for either single-family or multiple-family habitations. 
    Reverse frontage means a lot abutting two (2) parallel streets with access to only one (1) street. 
    Right-of-way means the strip of land dedicated to public use lying between the property lines of a street, alley, crosswalk, or easement title to which shall rest in the public for the purpose stated in such dedication. 
    Servitude means a strip reserved for public utilities, drainage and other public purposes, the title of which shall remain with the property owner, subject to the right of use designated in the reservation of servitude. 
    Sight flare means the angle of vision at an intersection. 
    Street means a right-of-way dedicated to public use that provides principal vehicular and pedestrian access to adjacent properties. 
    Subdivider means a person, firm or corporation or any agent thereof dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision. 
    Subdivision means the division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two (2) of more lots, plats, sites, or other divisions of land for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale or of building development, and with regard to parishes, for the purpose of sale or of building development for purposes other than agricultural. It includes resubdivision and, when appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or territory subdivided. 
    Subdivision preliminary plat means a drawing or set of drawings showing a proposed subdivision of land together with the public improvements which are to be installed therein. 
    Zoning and planning administrator (ZPA) means an individual appointed by the city council to enforce zoning and/or planning ordinances, conduct reviews of plats submitted for subdivisions or resubdivision, conduct public hearings, and other matters pertinent to the regulation and development of subdivisions. 
(Ord. No. 1314, § 1(13-52), 3-8-05) 
Sec. 13-63. - Procedure. 
    The following procedures will be utilized for the purpose of reviewing the development of subdivisions. 
(a)  Conceptual (optional). The conceptual approval phase of the procedure allows the commission to review the plan prior to an investment of undue effort and funds by the developer. This phase allows the commission a chance to review the concept of the plan and to insure that the developer fully understands the regulations set forth in this article. The prerequisites of the conceptual plan are outlined in subsection 13-64(a). 
(1)  The developer or his agent shall submit to the zoning and planning administrator five (5) copies of the conceptual plan at least thirty (30) days prior to the meeting of the commission. 
(2)  The staff shall review the conceptual plan and make its recommendations in writing prior to its meeting. Approval of the conceptual plan by the commission allows the developer to proceed to the next phase, the preliminary plan. If the plan is disapproved, the developer must resubmit the conceptual plan with the suggested changes, as outlined by the commission. 
(b)  Preliminary plats. 
(1)  The developer or his agent shall submit to the zoning and planning administrator and/or its staff five (5) full size copies of the preliminary plan at least thirty (30) days prior to the meeting of the commission. The developer must obtain utility service agreements from either public or private utility concerns. This agreement must state that the utility concern can adequately support the proposed development and indicate what cost, if any, must be borne by the developer. 
(2)  A subdivision fee is required and payable to the City of Crowley. (See fee schedule, section 13-66.) 
(3)  As outlined in subsection 13-64(b), it shall be the responsibility of the developer or his agent to furnish the ZPA with the names and addresses of all adjacent property owners and a fee payable to the City of Crowley to cover the cost of a public hearing and notification of adjacent property owners when submitting the preliminary plat. (See fee schedule, section 13-66.) 
(4)  One (1) week prior to the commission meeting, a public hearing will be called to discuss the proposed subdivision. The staff will send notification of the hearing to the developers and adjacent landowners by certified mail at least five (5) days prior to the hearing. The notice shall state the purpose, date, time and place of the hearing and include a copy of the proposed preliminary plat. If subsequent addendums alter the proposed plan in a minor or nominal manner, an additional public hearing will not be necessary. The decision to call future public hearings will be at the discretion of the commission. 
(5)  The staff will review the comments and opinions expressed at the hearing and the comments of the utility concerns prior to the formulation of written recommendations. 
(6)  Upon review, the commission may grant approval of the preliminary plat. This approval allows the developer to proceed with the development of engineering plans for the construction of the subdivision. If the commission rejects the preliminary plat, the developer is required to resubmit the revised or amended plat for further review. 
(c)  Engineering (designated review agent). Prior to the initiation of the construction of the subdivision, the engineering plans for construction must be reviewed and approved by the designated review agent. 
(1)  A civil engineer, registered in the state, is required to submit to the designated review agent five (5) copies of the construction plans and specifications. A fee is required for review of streets and sewer and for final review of streets and sewer. (See fee schedule, section 13-66.) 
(2)  The DRA will evaluate the construction plans and submit comments in writing. 
(3)  The DRA will either approve or disapprove of engineering plans. Approval of the plans entitle the developer to begin actual construction. If the plan is disapproved, revisions will be made and resubmitted for review. 
(4)  Upon approval by the DRA, the ZPA may record the approved plat with the parish clerk of court providing a performance bond is issued to the City of Crowley in the amount of one hundred (100) per cent of all improvements. In the absence of a performance bond, no sale or recordation is to take place until final approval is received and accepted by the commission. 
(d)  Final. Final approval of a subdivision is granted after the development has been inspected as constructed and the engineering certification has been submitted to and accepted by the designated review officer. 
(1)  The written request for final approval must be submitted at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date requested for final inspection. The developer's engineer shall submit certification that the construction was completed as per approved plans under his seal as a registered civil engineer in the state. 
(2)  As-built plans must be submitted if significant changes were made during construction. These plans must be submitted to the ZPA or its staff at least fifteen (15) days prior to final inspection. 
(3)  The recommendation of the commission together with the engineering certification shall be submitted by the commission to the city council prior to its meeting. Acceptance of the subdivision for perpetual maintenance may be expected upon approval. It is the responsibility of the commission to submit the necessary maps to the city council for their concurrence, approval and acceptance of improvements for public and perpetual maintenance. 
(4)  Once final approval is granted, the ZPA may record the plat and the developer may begin sale of the lots in the subdivision. Lots that are not part of a formally approved plat may not be sold. A fee is required for filing and recordation. (See fee schedule, section 13-66.) 
(5)  For a period of twelve (12) months after acceptance of the work the subdivider shall maintain and keep all filled trenches, pipes, manholes, structures, paving, etc., constructed by him in good condition, making and bearing the cost to repair such defects in material or workmanship as may develop or be discovered. The subdivision subdivider shall file with the commission, a surety bond securing to the City of Crowley the satisfactory performance of this work for a period of one (1) year from the date of such bond. The amount of the bond shall be ten (10) per cent of the cost of the improvements as determined by the designated review agent. The City of Crowley's legal counsel shall approve the form of the bond. The bond shall be subject to cancellation only upon written approval of the designated review agent. 
(6)  One copy of the approved and recorded plat shall be submitted to the Crowley City Planning Commission, zoning administrator, designated review agent, code enforcement officer and to the Crowley City Council each for their files and records. 
(Ord. No. 1314, § 1(13-53), 3-8-05) 
Sec. 13-64. - Plans. 
    This section outlines the prerequisites required for each phase in the approval of a plan. All materials submitted to the ZPA become the property of the planning commission and shall be returned to the developer only insofar as revisions or changes are requested. It is requested that tracings, reproducible or original supporting documents not be submitted until approval has been granted. At this time the original documents will be signed in order that reproductions will show approval. 
(a)  Conceptual. 
(1)  Name of proposed subdivision. 
(2)  Name of developer. 
(3)  Name of planner or planning firm. 
(4)  Location by section, township and range. 
(5)  Date, scale (maximum 1" = 800') and north arrow. 
(6)  Boundary of proposed subdivision. 
(7)  Major existing streets and roads. 
(8)  Proposed major streets and roads. 
(9)  Probable land use (single-family, multiple-family, commercial, industrial, etc.) for land within the tract. 
(10)  Important existing features, i.e. pipelines, utility rights-of-way, well locations, etc. 
(11)  MSL GRID-300 feet maximum. 
(b)  Preliminary. 
(1)  Name of proposed subdivision. 
(2)  Name of developer. 
(3)  Name of planner or planning firm. 
(4)  Location of section, township and range. 
(5)  Date, scale (minimum 1" =200') and north arrow. 
(6)  Proposed street names, lot and block numbers. 
(7)  Alignments of existing streets, rights-of-way, easements and servitudes which join or cross the proposed subdivision. 
(8)  Section, township, range, city limit and/or parish boundaries which abut or cross the proposed subdivision. 
(9)  Geometric layout of lots, blocks, streets, rights-of-way, easements and servitudes. 
(10)  Adjacent property owners and mailing addresses may be listed on a separate sheet, and notations should be made on plat. 
(c)  Engineering. 
(1)  Name of proposed subdivision. 
(2)  Name of developer. 
(3)  Signature of civil engineer, seal. 
(4)  Vicinity map. 
(5)  Location by section, township and range. 
(6)  Date, scale (minimum 1" = 50') north arrow. 
(7)  Proposed street names. 
(8)  Alignment with existing streets, rights-of-way, easements and servitudes. 
(9)  Section, township, range, city limits and/or parish boundaries which abut or cross the proposed subdivision. 
(10)  Description of proposed improvements, i.e. materials, typical street cross-sections, etc. 
(11)  Final alignment of streets and sewerage as built records subject to inspection by city engineer and inspector. 
(12)  Final drainage plan showing existing contours at one-foot intervals, or less, if requested by the planning commissioner engineer. 
(13)  Plans showing location of utilities, light standards and fire hydrants. 
(14)  Protective covenant, where applicable. 
(15)  Method of sewerage disposal, tie-in with existing collection systems, lagoons, lift stations, force main, etc. 
(16)  Profiles of all streets and ditches shall be submitted and where open ditches are used for drainage, a minimum size and grade of pipe to be used shall be denoted. 
(Ord. No. 1314, § 1(13-54), 3-8-05) 
Sec. 13-65. - Standards. 
(a)  Lots. 
(1)  Minimum residential size shall conform to zoning regulations. 
(2)  Lots on major street intersections and at all acute angles intersections will be designated to provide an adequate sight flare. 
(3)  No fence, wall hedge, or shrub planting which obstructs sight lines at elevations between street level and eight (8) feet above roadways shall be placed or permitted to remain on any corner lot with the triangular area formed by the street property lines and a line connecting them at points twenty-five (25) feet from the intersections of the street lines, or in case of a rounded property corner, from the intersection of the street property lines extended. The same sight line limitations shall apply on any lot within ten (10) feet from the intersection of a street property line with the edge of driveway or alley pavement. 
(b)  Blocks. No block shall be acceptable longer that eight hundred fifty (850) linear feet between cross streets except as adjacent development of terrain may dictate or in the opinion of the planning commission, would enhance the public safety. The commission may require, where blocks exceed the maximum distance, a pedestrian crosswalk with a ten-foot minimum right-of-way where the nearest portion of the block is more than eight hundred fifty (850) feet from a public or semi-public building or facility. 
(c)  Streets 
(1)  Major streets rights-of-way shall conform to the widths designated in the major thoroughfare plan. 
(2)  Collector streets shall have a minimum right-of-way of fifty (50) feet where subsurface drainage exists, or sixty (60) feet where open ditches are used, or an additional right-of-way where the planning commission deems necessary. 
(3)  Minor streets shall have a minimum right-of-way of forty (40) feet where subsurface drainage exists, fifty (50) feet where open ditches are used, or an additional right-of-way where the planning commission deems necessary. 
(4)  In cases where the subdivision includes or adjoins an existing major street having a width less than the minimum established herein, the commission may require the dedication of additional right-of-way widths. 
(5)  Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet shall be avoided. 
(6)  Cul-de-sacs shall have a minimum turning radius of forty-seven (47) feet. 
(7)  Servitude of five (5) feet in width may be provided on each side of side or rear lot lines as may be necessary for utility purposes. 
(8)  Servitudes for subsurface drainage, sanitary sewers, and public facilities and provisions shall be made for the maintenance and operation thereof. 
a.  Storm drainage shall be located within the street right-of-way. Special servitudes may be required for interconnections or outfall purposes within the subdivision. 
b.  Publicly owned sanitary sewer lines may not be located in rear or side lot servitudes. 
c.  Light standards may be located on either side of the street right-of-way or in an easement designated for this purpose or may be located in the center of the median of the boulevard. There shall be one (1) standard at each intersection and the spacing of standards shall not exceed two hundred (200) feet and shall not be less than one hundred fifty (150) feet except with special permission of the governing authority or their appointed representative. 
d.  Primary electric, gas, and telephone facilities may not be located in rear or side lot servitudes. 
(9)  Off-street parking shall conform to zoning ordinance. 
(d)  Drainage. Wherever drainage channels exist within a subdivision, adequate servitudes shall be dedicated on both sides of the facility for construction improvements and future maintenance. The commission shall approve the widths of servitudes. Lots sold along the servitude shall be subject to the servitude and the protective covenants shall so stipulate. 
(1)  Open ditches and channels will be designed to provide adequate runoff for the area being served. 
(2)  Subsurface drainage shall conform to Crowley's existing ordinances. 
The maximum grade will be one that will produce a velocity of eight (8) feet per second. 
The minimum grade that will be used will produce a velocity of three (3) feet per second. Minimum size pipe of twelve (12) inches will be utilized. 
The maximum length of pipe between each catch basin and/or manhole will be: 
12" and 15" 150' 18" 300' 24" and 36" 400' 42" and larger 600'  
A minimum time of five (5) minutes will be used for overland flow based on a minimum duration of five (5) minutes. 
Catch basins shall be placed at or near property lines in mid-block and at the intersection as the grade may dictate. 
(e)  Residential. 
(1)  All streets shall be hard-surfaced with adequate drainage. 
(2)  All developments within Crowley shall be constructed to the following minimum requirements: 
a.  Streets shall consist of a minimum of twenty-four-foot wide cement stabilized base ten (10) inches thick with a twenty-two-foot wide plant mix asphaltic concrete surface two (2) inches thick, and shall require soil testing by a properly qualified engineer to determine the need for lime treatment prior to soil cement treatment. 
b.  Four-foot minimum width compacted shell or gravel shoulders. 
c.  Open ditches as allowed which fit the minimum grades stated previously. 
(3)  If the developer elects to utilize curb and gutter and subsurface drainage, the following minimum requirements will apply: 
a.  Curb and gutter with subsurface drainage with hard surfacing of either Portland cement concrete pavement, six (6) inches thick with acceptable base course asphaltic concrete pavement and base course as specified in subsection (e)(2)a. above with a minimum width of twenty-seven (27) feet measured from back-to-back of curb. 
(4)  Fire hydrants shall have a minimum spacing of four hundred (400) feet with no area in the subdivision exceeding five hundred (500) feet from any fire hydrant. This spacing may be altered slightly to conform to the location of lot lines. 
(5)  Street signs shall be located eight (8) feet above the ground with a minimum sign height of four (4) inches and shall conform to the city standards. 
(f)  Commercial/Light industry. 
(1)  All streets shall be hard-surfaced with adequate drainage and conform to either of the following standards. The minimum standards shall be the option of the developer subject to approval by the Crowley Planning Commission: 
a.  Either eight-inch Portland cement concrete with acceptable base course or three-inch asphaltic concrete pavement with a stabilized base design as specified in subsection (e)(2)a. above, twenty-four (24) feet in width and open ditches with a minimum six-foot wide compacted aggregate shoulder; or 
b.  Shall consist of streets with curb and gutter and subsurface drainage and eight-inch thick Portland cement pavement or three-inch asphaltic concrete pavement with acceptable base course as specified in subsection (e)(2)a. above, thirty-two (32) feet back-to-back of curb. 
(2)  Sewerage disposal will be as required by the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals or applicable federal agencies. 
(3)  Off-street parking and loading space shall be shown on the plat for every group of lots proposed or developed for commercial and industrial usage to provide a minimum of one (1) loading space for every eight hundred (800) square feet of lot area and twenty (20) per cent of the gross lot area for off street parking. Each space shall be provided on private property with individual access to the street right-of-way. 
(g)  Industrial. 
(1)  Rights-of-way in an industrial subdivision shall be a minimum width of eighty (80) feet. 
(2)  Waste disposal shall be as required by the Louisiana Department of Health and Hospitals or applicable federal agencies. 
(3)  A bond shall be provided to assure the construction of an eight-inch water line or a certified letter shall be submitted from the appropriate utility commission stating that a suitable arrangement has been made to cover the subdivision. 
(4)  Roadways will be constructed of either Portland cement concrete pavement or asphaltic concrete pavement to the following minimum specifications: 
a.  Portland cement concrete pavement, where used, must be a minimum of eight (8) inches thick with acceptable base course twenty-eight (28) feet in width placed on a sub-grade compacted to a minimum of ninety-five (95) per cent of maximum theoretical density as specified by a properly qualified soils engineer. 
b.  Asphaltic concrete pavement where used, shall have an equivalent structural design of Portland concrete pavement as indicated in subsection (4)a. 
(5)  Shoulders of each side of the roadway shall be a minimum width of ten (10) feet with an aggregate four (4) inches thick compacted. Any of the following aggregate type surfaces may be used providing that a minimum of ninety-five (95) per cent of the maximum theoretical density of the aggregate is used. 
a.  610 limestone. 
b.  Recycled asphalt pavement. 
(6)  Off-street parking shall be as outlined in subsection (c). 
(h)  Mobile home parks. 
(1)  All streets in mobile home parks shall be hard-surfaced with adequate drainage and in basic compliance with the residential streets and sewerage requirements as outlined in subsections (d) and (e) of this section. However, should the developer elect to place curb and gutter and subsurface drainage, the minimum street width may be reduced to twenty-four (24) feet back-to-back of curb. 
(2)  Off-street parking shall be as outlined in subsection (c) herein. 
(Ord. No. 1314, § 1(13-55), 3-8-05) 
Sec. 13-66. - Permits, fees and costs. 
    The following amounts shall be paid for the issuance of a permit, the filing of a plat, notice of publication of public hearings and filing and recording costs of plats and documents as set out herein. 
(a)  Before any proceedings may be conducted by the board or by the planning and zoning administrator, the following amounts shall be paid by the applicant: 
(1)  Preliminary plat review: $200.00 plus $5.00 per lot; $150.00 for public hearing, letters and notice. 
(2)  Final plat review: $200.00 plus $5.00 per lot. 
(3)  Recordation: $60.00 plus the actual cost of recording at the Acadia Parish clerk of court's office. 
(4)  Preliminary and final plat: $300.00 plus $5.00 per lot; $150.00 for public hearing, letters and notice; $60.00 recording. 
(5)  Construction, planning and acceptance preliminary plans streets and sewers: 
a.  Preconstruction review: $100.00 street; $100.00 sewer. 
b.  Postconstruction review: $100.00 street; $100.00 sewer. 
(6)  Recordation of acceptance: $60.00 plus actual cost of recording at the Acadia Parish clerk of court's office. 
(b)  No action shall be commenced, review undertaken or plats recorded until all fees and costs assessed herein have been fully paid by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1314, § 1(13-56), 3-8-05) 
Sec. 13-67. - Implementation. 
(a)  Administration. The Crowley City Planning Commission shall administer the provisions of these regulations. Appeals from a decision rendered by said commission shall go to the appropriate governing body and the decision of the commission may be overridden by a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of said body. 
(b)  Variance. Where the commission finds that hardships may result with the strict compliance of these regulations, it may vary the regulations so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest secured, provided however, that such variation will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of these regulations. 
(c)  Violations. Any person having been properly notified that he is in violation of these regulations shall have such violations corrected within sixty (60) days, and each day thereafter shall constitute a separate offense. Any person violating or refusing to comply with any provision of these regulations shall, upon conviction, be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) (L.A. R.S. 33:101-119, et al) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 1314, § 1(13-57), 3-8-05) 
Sec. 13-68. - Severance clause. 
    If any section, clause, paragraph, provision or portion of these regulations shall be held invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, such holding shall not affect any other section, paragraph, clause, provision or portion of these regulations. 
    All former ordinances or parts of ordinances by the Crowley City Council conflicting with or inconsistent with the provisions of these regulations are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 1314, § 1(13-58), 3-8-05)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - State laws adopted. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority conferred by Louisiana Revised Statutes, Section 32:4(C) as amended, the provisions of Louisiana Revised Statutes, Title 32, Chapter 1, the Highway Regulatory Act, as now enacted and as hereafter amended, and all regulations of the state department of transportation and the secretary of the department of public safety, as now or hereafter adopted pursuant thereto, except for such provisions and regulations as by their nature can have no application in the city and except as now or hereafter otherwise provided in this Code or by ordinance, be and the same are hereby adopted.
