Sec. 14-2. - Weight limits of vehicles on city streets and prohibition of certain vehicles on city streets. 
(a)  Over 5,000 pounds. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or to permit the driving of any vehicle weighing more than five thousand (5,000) pounds on any of the streets of the city, save and except that it shall be lawful for any such vehicle to travel on or over any such street in the event that there is no alternate route to and from any business establishment situated in the city; in which event, such vehicle shall travel the most direct route to and from such business established so long as such vehicles are travelling on or over any such street or streets. 
(b)  Driving 18-wheelers. It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or to permit the driving of a vehicle commonly known or identified as an eighteen-wheeler on any streets situated within the corporate limits of the city save and except those streets designated as state or federal highways or specifically marked as a truck route, save and except that it shall be lawful for any such vehicle to drive on any street within the city solely for the purpose of pickup and delivery from any business establishment situated in the city; in which such event, such vehicle shall travel the most direct route to and from such business establishment from any federal or state highway or designated truck route, save and except that it shall be lawful to drive the tractor portion only (meaning that the trailer portion has been completely disconnected) on any street solely for the purpose of going to or returning from the driver's official residence; in which event, such vehicles shall travel the most direct route from the driver's place of business or from the aforesaid state or federal highway or truck route. 
(c)  Parking 18-wheelers. It shall be unlawful to park vehicles commonly known or identified as eighteen-wheelers whether it is the tractor portion, trailer portion or both on any streets or other public places situated within the corporate limits of the city or on any property not designated as a commercial or business parking area providing for the parking of eighteen-wheelers, save and except that the driver of such vehicle shall be permitted to park the tractor portion only (meaning that the trailer portion has been completely disconnected) at his official residence provided it is situated completely upon the property occupied by his residence and not upon any property belonging to the city. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision or regulations herein shall be punished as provided in section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 16-4; Ord. No. 1132, § 1, 3-13-90) 
Sec. 14-3. - Vehicles and livestock prohibited in certain places. 
(a)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful to ride, drive or operate any vehicle or horse, mule, cattle or other livestock in the following places: 
(1)  On any sidewalk, banquette, neutral ground or parkway; 
(2)  In any public park or cemetery; 
(3)  Upon the grounds of any school. 
(b)  Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not prohibit the crossing of a sidewalk on a properly constructed driveway, nor shall this section be applicable to vehicles or livestock on a roadway designed for vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1965, § 8-43) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 4; prohibited acts in parks, playgrounds, recreation areas, § 7-54. 
Sec. 14-4. - Bicycles and skateboards prohibited on sidewalks in C-4 zoning area. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to ride a bicycle or skateboard on any sidewalk other than while crossing a sidewalk at a properly constructed driveway in the area designated C-4 Central Business District as shown on the official zoning map of the City of Crowley. 
(Code 1965, § 20-5; Ord. No. 1141, § 1, 2-11-92) 
Sec. 14-5. - Skating, toy vehicles prohibited on roadways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to skate, ride on roller skates, or on a toy wagon, tricycle, or other similar toy vehicle in the traffic roadway of any street. 
(Code 1965, § 16-6) 
Sec. 14-6. - Garage keepers to report damaged vehicles. 
    The person in charge of any garage or repair shop to which is brought any motor vehicle which shows evidence of having been involved in a serious accident or struck by any bullet shall report to the nearest police station within twenty-four (24) hours after such motor vehicle is received, giving the engine number and the name and address of the owner or operator of such vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 16-7) 
Sec. 14-7. - Impounding vehicles. 
    Any vehicle found parked in violation of this chapter or any parking regulation, and any vehicle found in charge of, or operated by, any unlicensed person, or any person under the influence of intoxicating liquor or narcotic drug, shall be taken in charge by a police officer of the city and impounded or stored, and all costs and charges for removing and impounding the vehicle shall be paid by the owner thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 16-8) 
Cross reference- Junk vehicles, § 9-28 et seq.; abandoned vehicles, § 14-43. 
Sec. 14-8. - Authorization for use on city streets of certain unlicensed vehicles; permitting; annual inspection. 
    The ordinance from which this section was derived is established for the purpose of authorizing and permitting the use and operation of certain unlicensed vehicles as defined herein on public roads, streets and alleyways within the corporate limits of the City of Crowley under the rules, regulations and definitions provided herein and subject to the penalties for violations thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1450, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 14-8.1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this section, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings, to-wit: 
    Unlicensed vehicle. A golf cart or other four-wheeled vehicle operated by an electric motor or gasoline or diesel motor capable of speed of not more than twenty-five (25) miles per hour may be operated on the public streets, roadways and alleyways, except state highways, within the corporate limits of the City of Crowley by any person holding a valid driver's license issued by the State of Louisiana Department of Motor Vehicles or the corresponding agency of any state or possession of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 1450, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 14-8.2. - Hours of operation; crossings. 
(a)  Such vehicles defined herein may be operated only between the hours of sunrise and sunset Greenwich Mean Time (GMT) as calculated for Crowley, Louisiana. 
(b)  Such vehicles shall be subject to and operated under the provisions of the Louisiana Revised Statutes Title 32 as amended. 
(c)  These provisions shall not apply to "authorized emergency vehicles" which shall mean a vehicle owned or leased by the Crowley Fire Department or the Crowley Police Department and so designated by the fire chief or police chief for the purposes of responding to an emergency or for official use in connection with permitted events and/or parades within the corporate limits of the City of Crowley. 
(Ord. No. 1450, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 14-8.3. - Permitting; annual inspection; requirements and fees. 
(a)  All such vehicles shall be operated on public streets, roadways and alleyways within the corporate limits of the City of Crowley except "state maintained highways" as defined by law or maintained by the Louisiana Department of Transportation and Development. 
(b)  All such vehicles shall be issued an annual permit by the City of Crowley Police Department after passing physical inspection. The annual fee for permit and inspection shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00) which is to be paid to the City of Crowley at the time of the inspection. 
(c)  All such vehicles shall meet the requirements for equipment operated on public roads of the State of Louisiana, including but not limited to brakes, lights, safety equipment and controls as provided in Louisiana Revised Statutes Title 32. In addition, such vehicles shall be equipped with one shield mounted rearview mirror and driver's side exterior rearview mirror capable of providing a minimum rear sight fixture to the operator of not less than one hundred (100) feet. 
(d)  The owner of such vehicle shall maintain liability insurance coverage on the vehicles with a good and valid insurance carrier and provide a certificate of insurance showing valid insurance coverage on the vehicle for the purpose of public liability for the owner and any operator thereof and coverage for bodily injury to person or persons in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per person and three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per accident and property damage coverage of not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) per incident. The certificate of insurance shall be carried on or in the vehicle at all times and shall be displayed to any law enforcement officer requesting same at any time. 
(e)  The permit shall include a waiver of liability by the owner of the vehicle of any claims, causes of action or right of action against the City of Crowley for bodily injury, property damage or otherwise, occurring from the use and operation of the permitted vehicle and shall include a hold harmless and indemnity clause in favor of the City of Crowley of any such claims, which hold harmless and indemnity shall include all costs thereof including but not limited to attorney's fees and other expenses. 
(f)  The owner of the vehicle shall sign an agreement and acknowledgment of the permit conditions expressly agreeing to all the terms and conditions of the permit, including but not limited to the provisions of subsection (e) above. 
(Ord. No. 1450, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Sec. 14-8.4. - Violations; penalties. 
    Any person operating an unpermitted vehicle within the corporate limits of the City of Crowley and found guilty of violating the provisions of the ordinance from which this section was derived, including but not limited to operating the vehicle without a permit, insurance or a valid driver's license, failing to meet the regulatory requirements for equipment or failure of equipment to operate properly shall be fined not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) per violation and subject to a jail term of not more than sixty (60) days or both. 
(Ord. No. 1450, § 1, 11-13-12) 
Secs. 14-9-14-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION 

Sec. 14-20. - Driving while incapacitated. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use, drive or operate any motor vehicle while suffering from a physical disability, infirmity or affliction which renders such person unable to operate a motor vehicle in a safe manner. 
(Code 1965, § 16-31) 
Sec. 14-21. - Speed limits-For motor vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in the City of Crowley in excess of the following speeds on any streets or portion of streets listed below: 
(1)  35 miles per hour. 
North Parkerson Avenue from the Court Circle to the north corporate limits, 
Eastern Avenue from Hutchinson Avenue to the south corporate limits, 
Except as provided in subsection (4) of this section. 
(2)  30 miles per hour. 
On any other street, except as provided in subsections (3) and (4) of this section; 
(3)  25 miles per hour. 
Ash Street from the intersection of Eastern Avenue to the corporate limits, Azelea Road, Avenue B from the intersection of 15th Street to West Bayou Court, West Bayou Court, West Bayou Drive, Blue Bonnet, Blue Lake Drive, Blue Rose, Broad Acres Drive, Bruner Avenue, Buck Sweeney Drive, Camelia Street, Camp Street, Canal Street, Cedar Street, Cherry Street, Clay Street, Clark Court, Cypress Drive, Avenue D from the intersection of 15th Street to Henrietta Drive, Elm Street, Avenue F from the Bayou Blanc Bridge to the corporate limits, Fairway Drive, 15th Street from the intersection of Parkerson Avenue East to the corporate limits, 4th Street and 5th Street from the intersection of Eastern Avenue East to the corporate limits, Avenue G from the intersection of Mill Street South to the corporate limits, Geesey Avenue, Glennwood Avenue, Grace Pete, Grady Poullard, Greenbriar Avenue, Gulf Rose, Avenue H from the intersection of Mill Street South to the corporate limits, Henrietta Drive, Holly Street, Hoyt Avenue, Huval Street, James Street, Jeanette Street, John F. Kennedy Drive, Judge Canan Drive, Keller Street, Avenue L from the intersection of Northern Avenue to 17th Street, Labelle, Lawson Street, Lennie Johnson, Lewis Street, Avenue M from the intersection of 4th Street to 5th Street, Avenue M from the intersection of Mear Street to the corporate limits, Magnolia Drive, May Street, Avenue N from the intersection of Mear Street to the corporate limits, Avenue O from the intersection of Mear Street to the corporate limits, Oak Street, East Park Avenue, Parkerson Avenue from the intersection of Mill Street to Pine Street, Pine Street, Pintail, Rue Aline, 17th Street from the intersection of Avenue I to the corporate limits, 16th Street, Spruce Street, Standard Mill Road, Sterling Drive, Stutes Street, Sweeney Street, Texas Street, 3rd Street from the intersection of Parkerson Avenue East to the corporate limits, Truman Street, Westwood Drive: 
Except as provided in subsection (4) of this section. 
(4)  15 miles per hour. 
On any street adjacent to any school, public park, public playground or hospital and for a distance of one-half block in any direction from the property line of any school, public park, public playground or hospital as posted. 
(b)  Signs shall be erected notifying the traveling public of the maximum speed limits provided for herein. 
(c)  Any person violating any of said provisions or regulations shall be punished by a fine of not less than the amount shown in the below schedule as the minimum and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days or both within the discretion of the court as hereinafter listed, to-wit: 
Louisiana Revised Statute Charge (Offense) Minimum Fine LA R.S. 32:54 Speeding (01-10) $50.00 LA R.S. 32:54 Speeding (11-14) 65.00 LA R.S. 32:54 Speeding (15-19) 80.00 LA R.S. 32:54 Speeding (20 plus) 100.00  
(Code 1965, § 16-24; Ord. No. 1266, § 1, 4-8-03; Ord. No. 1381, § 26, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 14-22. - Same-For trucks. 
    It shall be unlawful to drive any truck, except a half-ton pickup truck, in excess of twenty-five (25) miles per hour in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 16-24) 
Sec. 14-23. - Right-of-way streets; four-way stop intersections. 
(a)  Designated. The following are hereby designated as right-of-way streets and avenues: 
(1)  All streets and avenues running east-west except at their intersections with the below-named streets; 
(2)  Avenue E from the south side of Front Street to Northern Avenue; 
(3)  Avenue F from the south corporate limits to Tenth Street, and from Twelfth Street to Northern Avenue; 
(4)  Avenue G from the south side of Front Street to Park Street; 
(5)  Avenue H from the southern corporate limits to the south side of Pine Street and from the north side of Pine Street to Second Street and from the north side of Second Street to the south side of Hutchinson Avenue and from the north side of Hutchinson Avenue to Northern Avenue; 
(6)  Eastern Avenue, except at its intersection with Northern Avenue; 
(7)  Parkerson Avenue, except at its intersection with Pine Street; 
(8)  Western Avenue, except at its intersection with Northern Avenue;

(16)  Buatt Avenue from the intersection of Northern Avenue to the north side of the intersection of 15th Street; 
(17)  South Avenue C from the south side of Mill Street to the north side of Pine Street;

(19)  Elm Street from the west side of Eastern Avenue to its intersection with the east side of Avenue I; and 
(20)  Avenue M at its intersection with Lawson Street. 
(b)  Duties. Vehicles traveling on right-of-way streets shall have right-of-way over all vehicles crossing or turning into right-of-way or avenue from any intersecting street or avenue, and any person driving a vehicle from any intersecting street or avenue across or into any right-of-way or avenue shall not proceed until such driver has ascertained that no vehicle is traveling the right-of-way street sufficiently near to the intersecting street or avenue to render a collision or accident probable; provided that the provisions of this section shall not apply at intersections where and when traffic is being controlled by automatic signal lights, or where and when a police officer assumes direction of traffic, provided further that vehicles composing a funeral procession (or any procession authorized by permit of the city to parade), shall not be required to stop at right-of-way streets if the first and leading vehicle of the procession has complied with this section; and providing further that the provisions of this section shall not apply to emergency vehicles. 
(c)  Four-way stop intersections. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein provided, the following described intersections shall be four-way stop intersections and each operator of a motor vehicle, upon approaching such intersection, shall bring such driver's vehicle to a complete stop and shall remain stopped until any vehicle previously stopped at the intersection has proceeded through such intersection and, thereafter, the drivers of vehicles on the intersecting streets shall, after stopping, alternate in proceeding through such intersection: 
(1)  Avenue E and First Street; 
(2)  Avenue G and Northern Avenue; 
(3)  Avenue H and Eighth Street; 
(4)  Avenue F and Pine Street; 
(5)  Avenue G and East Hutchinson Avenue; 
(6)  Avenue G and Fifth Street; 
(7)  Avenue G and Fourth Street; 
(8)  Avenue G and Third Street; 
(9)  Avenue F and Fifth Street; 
(10)  Northern Avenue and Western Avenue; 
(11)  Avenue E and Fifth Street; 
(12)  Avenue D and Fairway Drive; 
(13)  Hutchinson Avenue and Western Avenue; 
(14)  Avenue E and Hutchinson Avenue; 
(15)  Avenue F and Hutchinson Avenue; 
(16)  Avenue H and Hutchinson Avenue; 
(17)  Avenue K and Seventh Street; 
(18)  Avenue B and Seventeenth Street; 
(19)  Avenue J and First Street; 
(20)  Avenue H and Elm Street; 
(21)  Avenue N and Cedar Street; 
(22)  Third Street and Avenue N; 
(23)  Labelle and Eastpark Drive; 
(24)  Avenue D and Fourteenth Street; 
(25)  Avenue D and Fifteenth Street;

(27)  Fifteenth Street and Avenue B; 
(28)  Twelfth Street and Crawford Avenue; 
(29)  Seventh Street and Jacobs Avenue; 
(30)  Avenue N and Elm Street. 
(d)  Three-way stop intersections. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein provided, the following described intersections shall be three-way stop intersections and each operator of a motor vehicle, upon approaching such intersection, shall bring such driver's vehicle to a complete stop and shall remain stopped until any vehicle previously stopped at the intersection has proceeded through such intersection and, thereafter, the drivers of vehicles on the intersecting streets shall, after stopping, alternate in proceeding through such intersection: 
(1)  Avenue F and Twelfth Street; 
(2)  East Fifteenth Street and Avenue G; 
(3)  Western Avenue and Mill Street; 
(4)  Northern Avenue and William Egan Avenue; 
(5)  Texas Street and Huval Street;

(8)  Fourteenth Street and Avenue B;

(10)  J.D. Miller Drive and Marcel Thomas Avenue. 
(Code 1965, § 16-25; Ord. No. 1084, § 1, 8-14-84; Ord. No. 1089, § 1, 10-9-84; Ord. No. 1094, § 1, 3-12-85; Ord. No. 1100, § 1, 9-10-85; Ord. No. 1110, §§ 1, 2, 5, 4-14-87; Ord. No. 1117, §§ 1-4, 12-8-87; Ord. No. 1121, §§ 1, 2, 7-18-88; Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 10-11-88; Ord. No. 1125, § 1, 1-10-89; Ord. No. 1138, § 1, 6-17-91; Ord. No. 1139, § 1, 1-14-92; Ord. No. 1140, § 1, 2-11-92; Ord. No. 1146, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 1148, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 1151, §§ 1, 2, 3-9-93; Ord. No. 1170, §§ 1-3, 8-8-95; Ord. No. 1177, §§ 1, 2, 1-9-96; Ord. No. 1181, §§ 1, 2, 5-14-96; Ord. No. 1207, §§ 1, 2, 12-9-97; Ord. No. 1218, §§ 1, 2, 6-8-99; Ord. No. 1222, §§ 1-4, 12-14-99; Ord. No. 1233, § 1, 6-13-00; Ord. No. 1257, § 1, 7-9-02; Ord. No. 1258, § 1, 7-9-02; Ord. No. 1260, § 1, 8-13-02; Ord. No. 1265, §§ 1, 2, 1-14-03; Ord. No. 1329, § 1, 1-10-06; Ord. No. 1341, § 1, 7-11-06; Ord. No. 1363, § 1, 6-12-07; Ord. No. 1393, §§ 1, 2, 5-12-09; Ord. No. 1394, § 1, 6-9-09; Ord. No. 1426, § 1, 8-9-11; Ord. No. 1453, § 1, 5-14-13; Ord. No. 1457, §§ 1, 2, 9-10-13; Ord. No. 1473, § 1, 3-8-16; Ord. No. 1476, §§ 1, 2, 6-14-16; Ord. No. 1481, § 1, 11-8-16; Ord. No. 1485, § 1, 3-1-17) 
Sec. 14-24. - Receiving, discharging passengers while stopped at traffic-control device. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle stopped in obedience to a traffic-control signal to receive or discharge a passenger. 
(Code 1965, § 16-27) 
Sec. 14-25. - "U" turns. 
    No complete turn or reversal of direction, known as a "U" turn, shall be made on a roadway other than at an intersection. Such turns are prohibited at intersections where traffic is controlled by automatic traffic-control devices or signs prohibiting such turns. 
(Code 1965, § 16-30) 
State Law reference- "U" turns on hills and curves prohibited, R.S. 32:102. 
Sec. 14-26. - Permitting clinging to vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to knowingly permit any rider on roller skates, a bicycle, toy wagon or similar contrivance to hold on to or be pulled along by said motor vehicle. 
(Code 1965, § 16-32) 
Sec. 14-27. - Operator required to possess valid driver's license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle on any public thoroughfare within the corporate limits of the city unless such person has in such person's immediate possession a valid license issued to such person by this state or, if such person is a nonresident of this state, by the state of such person's residence, if one is required therein, authorizing such person to operate a vehicle of the type being operated and authorizing such person to operate a vehicle for the purpose for which it is being operated. 
(Code 1965, § 16-34) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, R.S. 23:402. 
Sec. 14-28. - Multiple lane roadways establishment and regulations. 
(a)  The following streets are hereby designated as multiple lane streets and avenues providing for two (2) lanes of traffic in each direction: 
(1)  Parkerson Avenue from its intersection with Mill Street northerly to its intersection with the corporate limits. 
(b)  Upon all multiple lane roadways designated as such, shall be provided with proper traffic control devices erected pursuant to the manual of specifications of uniform traffic control devices the State of Louisiana, pursuant to R.S. 32:235, all vehicles operated thereon shall be subject to the provisions of the State Highway Regulatory Act and the provisions of ordinances of the City of Crowley adopted pursuant to R.S. 32:41, along with other provisions of the State Highway Regulatory Act and other laws supplemental thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 16-35; Ord. No. 1217, § 1, 5-11-99) 
Sec. 14-29. - Railroads-Speed limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated, any locomotive, railroad train, or other railroad vehicle within the corporation limits of the city at a speed in excess of thirty (30) miles per hour. 
(Code 1965, § 8-37) 
Sec. 14-30. - Same-Blocking crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any railroad company or the employees thereof to block, obstruct or impede the free use of any street, sidewalk or public way with any locomotive, train, cars or other apparatus for a longer continuous time than five (5) minutes. 
(Code 1965, § 8-38) 
Cross reference- Street obstructions generally, § 13-9. 
Sec. 14-31. - Same-Safety precautions at crossings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated any railroad locomotive, railroad train, railroad car or other railroad vehicle over or across any public or private motor vehicular crossing, unprotected by a permanent flagman, automatic electric warnings or automatic electric stop gates, during any railroad car switching operations or to operate or cause to be operated any such railroad vehicle across any such motor vehicular crossing on any switch track unless or until a flagman or other crew member of such railroad vehicle enter such motor vehicular railroad crossing, flags down and stops approaching motor vehicular traffic and signals to the engineer, motorman or other person operating such railroad vehicle that such vehicles may safely enter and cross such motor vehicular crossing. 
(Code 1965, § 8-43.1) 
Sec. 14-32. - Reckless operation of a vehicle. 
(a)  Defined. Reckless operation of a vehicle is the operation of a motor vehicle, aircraft, vessel or other means of conveyance, in a criminally negligent or reckless manner. 
(b)  [Penalty.] Whoever commits reckless operation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days or both such fine and imprisonment within the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 1105, § 1, 8-12-86; Ord. No. 1381, § 27, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 14-33. - Hit-and-run driving. 
(a)  Definitions. "Hit-and-run driving" is the intentional failure of the driver of a vehicle involved in, or causing any accident, to stop such vehicle at the scene of the accident, to give his identity and render reasonable aid; "to give his identity", for the purpose of this article, shall mean that the driver of any vehicle involved in any accident shall give his name, address and the license number of the vehicle, or shall report the accident to the police. 
(b)  [Penalty.] Whoever commits the crime of hit-and-run shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined no less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days or both such fine and imprisonment within the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 1105, § 2, 8-12-86; Ord. No. 1381, § 28, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 14-34. - Exhaust assisted braking devices defined, prohibited and penalty for violation. 
(a)  Definition. A device which utilizes the power of an engine to produce a power absorbing and retarding effect to assist the slowing or braking of a vehicle (commonly known as "Jake Brakes") which increases engine noise and sound through the exhaust system while in use. 
(b)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful to operate or use engine-powered braking devices within the corporate limits of the City of Crowley, Louisiana. 
(c)  Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not apply to emergency vehicles or equipment. 
(d)  Penalty. Any person upon conviction shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and may be incarcerated for not more than thirty (30) days in jail, or both. 
(Ord. No. 1295, § 1, 8-10-04) 
Secs. 14-35-14-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING 

Sec. 14-39. - Penalty for parking violations. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, any person committing or attempting to commit any violation of the regulations governing the parking of, standing and stopping of vehicles, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than forty dollars ($40.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) or imprisoned for not more than ten (10) days, or both such fine and imprisonment, in the discretion of the court. 
(Code 1965, § 16-43; Ord. No. 1189, § 1, 8-13-96; Ord. No. 1381, § 29, 3-11-08) 
Cross reference- Impounding illegally parked vehicle, § 14-7. 
Sec. 14-40. - Displaying for sale. 
    It shall be unlawful to stop, stand or park a vehicle on any street for the purpose of offering or displaying the same for sale. 
(Code 1965, § 16-45) 
Sec. 14-41. - Parking to test, wash, grease, repair vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful to stop, stand or park any vehicle on any street for the purpose of testing such vehicle or repairing, washing, greasing or oiling it; provided that nothing contained herein shall prohibit the making of emergency repairs. 
(Code 1965, § 16-46) 
Sec. 14-42. - Designation of parking zones, spaces, prohibitions, violations and impoundment of vehicles. 
(a)  Designation of parking zones. The following named and described areas, streets or portions of streets shall constitute a designated parking zone as follows: 
(1)  Third street from Avenue F to Avenue G. 
(2)  Fourth Street from Avenue F to Avenue G. 
(3)  Fifth Street from Avenue F to Avenue G within the City of Crowley. 
(b)  Designation of parking spaces, parking in designated space. Individual parking spaces shall be marked parallel to the curb in the parking zones designated and described in subsection (a) hereof, said parking spaces to be designated by lines painted or durably marked on curbing or the surface of the street in standard spaces of twenty (20) feet. At each space so marked-off it shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle, car, truck, trailer or combination of motor vehicles and trailers in such a way that said vehicles shall not be entirely within the limits of the space so designated. 
(c)  Parking prohibited during designated hours. In said parking zones no motor vehicle, car, truck, trailer or combination thereof shall park, stand or stop in said designated parking spaces from 12:00 midnight to 5:00 a.m. 
(1)  The provisions of this subsection (c) shall be suspended during Rice Festival Weekend beginning Thursday at 5:00 p.m. until 1:00 a.m. the following Sunday. 
(d)  Violations and impounding of vehicles illegally parked. 
(1)  Any police officer and other law enforcement personnel shall have the power and authority to enforce the provisions of this section by issuance of citations to the operator and/or owner and/or both of the motor vehicle, car, truck, trailer or combination thereof parked, standing or stopped in violation of the provisions hereof; and 
(2)  Any police officer or other law enforcement personnel shall have the power and authority to impound and cause to be towed away and stored any motor vehicle, car, truck or combination of vehicles. The cost of towing, storage and redemption of such towed vehicle shall be paid by the owner or operator of such vehicle in addition to any other penalties imposed under this article. Upon the payment of all such costs the owner shall be entitled to have the property released. 
(Ord. No. 1189, § 2, 8-13-96; Ord. No. 1192, 2-12-97) 
Sec. 14-43. - Abandoned vehicles. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person or association of persons to abandon any motor vehicle on any street, alley or other public grounds of the city. 
(b)  "Abandoned" defined. Any motor vehicle remaining on any public street, alley or any other public grounds of the city, for five (5) days after notice, as hereinafter provided, shall be and constitute an abandoned motor vehicle. 
(c)  Notice to owner required. When the chief of police has reason to believe that a motor vehicle has been abandoned on a public street, alley or any other public grounds, such official shall give written notice to the owner of said vehicle that said vehicle shall be removed from the public street, alley or other public grounds, within five (5) days from service of such notice. 
(d)  Service of notice. Such notice shall be either personally served upon the owner of such motor vehicle or mailed to such owner by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, and shall give a reasonable description of the motor vehicle, including its license number, if any, and its location and shall be dated and signed by the said official. In the event that the owner of such vehicle is unknown and the identity of such owner can not be determined by reasonable inquiry, the above-mentioned notice shall be posted on the inside of the windshield or in some other prominent place on such vehicle, and such posting shall constitute service upon the owner of such vehicle. 
(e)  Disposition of unclaimed vehicles. After the lapse of the delay hereinabove provided for, the chief of police, as the case may be, shall remove such vehicle from the public street, alley or any other public grounds of the city and shall place such vehicle in the city dump or in any other place, at the discretion of such official, wherein such vehicle shall remain for a period of thirty (30) days. If such vehicle is not claimed by the owner thereof within such thirty-day period and all costs and charges paid, the city may dispose of such vehicle at public or private sale to defray all expenses of the said city in so removing and storing said vehicle; the charge for so removing any such motor vehicle is hereby fixed at the sum of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Code 1965, § 16-48) 
Cross reference- Junk vehicles, § 9-28 et seq.; impounding, § 14-7. 
State Law reference- Impounding vehicles authorized, R.S. 32:392; abandoned motor vehicles, etc., R.S. 33: 4876. 
Sec. 14-44. - Regulation at specific locations. 
(a)  The governing authority may from time to time designate areas in which parking is prohibited or prohibited during certain hours or limited in time or otherwise regulated or restricted. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to erect, install and maintain suitable signs or markings giving notice of such regulations and restrictions and it shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any such signs or markings. 
(b)  No person shall park any vehicle between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on all weekdays on the south side of 9th Street and the north side of 10th Street between Avenue L and Eastern Avenue. 
(c)  No person shall park any vehicle on the south side of Hutchinson Avenue between Moore Avenue and Stagg Avenue. 
(d)  No person shall park any vehicle on either side of North Avenue G between Park Street and North Crowley Drainage Ditch. 
(e)  No person shall park any vehicle on the south side of 1st Street between Avenue C and Avenue D. 
(f)  No person shall park any vehicle on the north side of 13th Street from Avenue H for a distance of one hundred (100) feet. 
(g)  No person shall park any vehicle on the north side of Northern Avenue between Milton Street and Chappuis Street. 
(h)  No person shall park any vehicle on the north side of 10th Street from its intersection with Avenue F for a distance of forty-five (45) feet from the crosswalk. 
(i)  No person shall park any vehicle on the north side of West 3rd Street from its intersection with Western Avenue for a distance of one hundred (100) feet from the crosswalk. 
(j)  No person shall park any vehicle on the east side of North Avenue F from its intersection with West 10th Street for a distance of one hundred (100) feet. 
(k)  No person shall park any vehicle on the north side of 13th Street east of its intersection with Avenue H for a distance of one hundred (100) feet. 
(l)  No person shall park any vehicle on the west side of Avenue N south of its intersection with 6th Street for a distance of one hundred (100) feet. 
(m)  No person shall park any vehicle on either side of Moore Avenue from its intersection with West Hutchinson Avenue to its intersection with 6th Street, on either side of 6th Street from its intersection with Moore Avenue to its intersection with Spann Avenue, on either side of Spann Avenue from its intersection with 6th Street to West Hutchinson Avenue, on either side of West Hutchinson Avenue from its intersection with Spann Avenue to its intersection with Moore Avenue. 
(n)  No person shall park any vehicle on the north side of 1st Street east of its intersection with Eastern Avenue to its intersection with North Avenue H. 
(o)  No person shall park any vehicle on the south side of West 15th Street east of its intersection with Chappuis Street and the intersection of Western Avenue during the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday. 
(p)  No person shall park any vehicle on 12th Street east of its intersection with Avenue K to its intersection with Eastern Avenue. 
(q)  No person shall park any vehicle on West Hutchinson Avenue west of its intersection with Mansfield Avenue and its intersection with Acadiana Railway Railroad right-of-way. 
(r)  No person shall park any vehicle on the east side of Avenue D south of its intersection with Mill Street and the intersection of Elm Street. 
(s)  No person shall park any vehicle on the north side of East Fifth Street for a distance of thirty (30) feet east of the west boundary line of Lot 10 of Block 76 of the Original City of Crowley. 
(t)  No person shall park any vehicle on the east side of Western Avenue beginning at the boundary of Lots 3 and 4 of Block 29 of the Original City of Crowley northerly to the intersection of 3rd Street. 
(u)  No person shall park any vehicle on the north side of West Mill Street from the intersection of the west right-of-way line of the extension of North Avenue C with the north right-of-way line of Mill Street to the intersection of the west right-of-way line of North Avenue E. 
(Code 1965, § 16-49; Ord. No. 1086, § 1, 8-14-84; Ord. No. 1088, §§ 1, 2, 10-2-84; Ord. No. 1090, § 1, 10-9-84; Ord. No. 1103, §§ 1, 2, 7-8-86; Ord. No. 1111, § 1, 5-12-87; Ord. No. 1130, § 1, 10-10-89; Ord. No. 1145, § 1, 3-10-92; Ord. No. 1156, § 1, 6-8-93; Ord. No. 1162, § 1, 11-8-94; Ord. No. 1200, § 1, 4-8-97; Ord. No. 1216, § 1, 1-12-99; Ord. No. 1243, § 1, 2-13-01; Ord. No. 1267, § 1, 6-10-03; Ord. No. 1417, § 1, 1-11-11; Ord. No. 1423, § 1, 7-12-11; Ord. No. 1434, § 1, 1-10-12; Ord. No. 1435, §§ 1, 2, 5-8-12) 
Sec. 14-45. - Parking long vehicles on Parkerson Avenue. 
    Trucks over eighteen (18) feet in length are prohibited from parking on Parkerson Avenue between Front Street and the Court House Square, provided that this section shall not apply to any truck or motor vehicle for which a written permit to park parallel with the curb for a specified time, not to exceed two (2) days, has been obtained from the chief of police and the mayor. 
(Code 1965, § 16-50) 
Sec. 14-46. - Handicapped parking places for persons with mobility impairments. 
    A restricted handicapped parking area for the mobility impaired consists of the parking space and the access aisle. No person shall park or place any object in a restricted parking area set aside and identified for use only by persons with physical disabilities unless the motor vehicle is actually transporting a person eligible for the mobility impaired placard or license plate bearing the international wheelchair symbol and the vehicle has displayed therein a mobility impaired parking placard as provided in Revised Statutes, Title 47, Chapter 463.4B(1), or license plate being the international wheelchair symbol issued pursuant to Revised Statutes, Title 47, Chapter 463.4A(1), other special mobility impaired license plate, or any subsequent replacement statutes dealing with parking for mobility impaired persons or as set forth by United States Public Law 100-641. 
(Ord. No. 1168, § 1, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 14-47. - Penalties for violation. 
(a)  Generally. Any person who either: 
(1)  Parks in such a restricted area without either a handicapped license plate or placard and is not actually transporting the person eligible for the license plate or placard; or 
(2)  Effectively prevents the use of such a restricted area, access aisle, or access ramp or curb in any manner; 
shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or shall be imprisoned for not more than ten (10) days, or both. On the second and subsequent offense, such person shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or shall be imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
(b)  Unlawful use of parking card or vehicle or specially licensed vehicle. Any person who utilizes a parking card or a vehicle bearing a special license plate, or person who allows his/her parking card or vehicle or specially licensed vehicle to be used to obtain or access handicapped parking privileges or has not transported a mobility impaired person in that vehicle prior to parking the vehicle, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than ten (10) days or both. On the second and subsequent offense, shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or shall be imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 1168, § 2, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 14-48. - Towing of illegally parked vehicles. 
    Any vehicles illegally parked in a zone designated for handicapped parking may be towed away from such zones and placed in storage. The cost of towing, storage and redemption of such towed vehicle shall be paid by the owner of such vehicle in addition to any fines designated in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1168, § 2, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 14-49. - Law enforcement authority to enter onto private property. 
    All law enforcement officers of the city are invested with authority to direct, control or regulate traffic or parking and are authorized to enter upon private property within their respective territorial jurisdictions to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1168, § 2, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 14-50. - Rebuttable presumption of operation. 
    When an officer issues a citation for an alleged violation of the laws governing parking in a handicapped parking space, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that the person/owner in whose name the vehicle is registered was the operator of the vehicle when the alleged violation was committed. 
(Ord. No. 1168, § 2, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 14-51. - Reciprocity of out-of-state license and placards. 
    Every mobility impaired person operating or otherwise being transported by a vehicle displaying the international symbol of the handicapped or the word "handicapped" on a valid special license plate, disabled veteran plate, or other handicapped parking permit prominently displayed shall be entitled to invoke all handicapped parking privileges provided in this article, without regard to the location of the issuing authority, or the residence or domicile of the person invoking the handicapped parking privileges. "Issuing authority," as defined in this section, shall mean only the Louisiana Office of Motor Vehicles of the Department of Public Safety and Corrections or comparable state level government issuing authorities in or outside the State of Louisiana. 
(Ord. No. 1168, § 2, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 14-52. - Theft of or criminal damage to handicapped signs. 
    Any person who commits theft (as defined in Revised Statutes 14:67) or commits an act of criminal damage to property (as defined in Revised Statutes 14:56) of a sign designating handicapped parking as defined in this article, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or imprisoned for thirty (30) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 1168, § 2, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 14-53. - Fire plug zones and fire lanes designated. 
(a)  Fire plug zones. It shall be unlawful to park in any zone so marked and designated as a fire plug zone preventing access by the fire department to fire plugs on any street, alleyway or parking area throughout the city. 
(b)  Fire lanes. There shall be no parking, standing or placing of any cars, trucks, trailers, apparatus, vehicles, portable buildings, or any item deemed as an obstruction by the fire department within fifty (50) feet of any exit, entrances, sprinkler system or fire department connections, and access to utility services servicing any shopping centers, malls, bowling alleys, theaters, hospitals, churches, apartment complexes, institutions, and any location in which there is ordinarily an assemblage of more than twenty (20) persons or any other area as deemed necessary for the protection of life and property from fire or explosions. 
(1)  Fire lanes shall be designated by the fire marshal or the local authority of the City of Crowley, and there shall be no parking, standing, or placing of any cars, trucks, trailers, apparatus, vehicles, portable buildings or any item deemed an obstruction by the fire department within such designated fire lanes. 
(2)  It shall be the responsibility of the owners and operators of facilities subject to this section to pay for and to have erected signs indicating any such areas designated as fire lanes by the department and said signs shall contain the following wording: "No Parking Fire Lane-By Order of the Fire Department-Tow Away Area." Said signs shall be white with red lettering and shall be located at a maximum of fifty (50) feet apart with signs facing in both directions. Signs indicating the amount of the fines specified in this section may be required to be placed by the department if necessary for repeated violations. 
(3)  It shall be the responsibility of the owners and operators of any facilities subject to this section to paint lines, outlining the area designated by the fire department as fire lanes. The painting of these lanes shall be yellow in color, and the width of the stripes shall be four (4) inches wide, and total length shall be that designated as the fire lanes by the fire marshal, or the local authority. Painted lanes shall be located five (5) feet from any curb or as specified by the fire department. 
(4)  Any owner or operator who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), or imprisonment not to exceed thirty (30) days or both. Each day's violation of the provisions hereof shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(5)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner and operator to see that the fire lane striping of the areas designated are maintained according to fire department requirements for visibility, and that signs are replaced when necessary. 
(6)  Any car, truck, trailer, vehicle or portable building found parked, standing or placed in a designated fire lane, shall be towed away and impounded by any police officer, fire inspector, or authorized representative. The owner of said car, truck, trailer, vehicle or portable building shall be responsible for all cost of impounding and storing of car, truck, trailer, vehicle or portable building. Upon the payment of such cost, the owner shall be entitled to have said property released. 
(7)  Owners and occupants of the property on which fire lanes are located are hereby charged with the responsibility of notifying the fire marshal, his local authorities, or local law enforcement officials of the existence of any vehicles parked in those lanes; and in the event that they are unable to contact the fire marshal, his local authorities, or local law enforcement officials, the owner and occupant are hereby authorized to remove any vehicle parked in those fire lanes by any reasonable means necessary and to assess the cost of removal of said vehicle until all costs incident to the removal and storage of said vehicle have been paid by owner. 
(8)  Temporary loading zones may be designated, but in no event shall an unattended vehicle be allowed to stand in a fire lane or at the entrance or exit to a shopping center. 
(9)  In any prosecution charging a violation of this section, proof that the vehicle described in the violations ticket was parked, standing, or placed in violation of this section, together with proof that the defendant named in the violation ticket was at the time of such parking, standing, or placement, the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence, a rebuttable prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was, in fact, the person who parked, stood or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, the alleged violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 1169, § 1, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 14-54. - Towing of vehicles parked in fire plug zones and designated fire lanes; costs to be paid by owner. 
    Any vehicle(s) illegally parked in a fire plug zone or designated fire lane preventing access to fire plugs, exits, entrances, sprinkler systems, fire department connections, utility services may be towed away from such zones and placed in storage. The costs of redemption of such towed vehicle shall be paid by the owner of such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 1169, § 1, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 14-55. - Authority for law enforcement to enforce ordinance on public and private property. 
    The Crowley City Police and other law enforcement personnel shall have the power and authority to enforce the provisions of this ordinance by issuance citations to the operator and/or owner, or both, of the vehicle or other object allegedly violating same, by arresting the operator and/or owner and charging them with the violation thereof, and by ordering the vehicle or other object towed away and stored at any time. If a vehicle is towed away and stored, the owner and/or operator shall be responsible for the payment of costs thereof, as also provided hereinabove. The Crowley City Police and other law enforcement personnel shall henceforth have full authority and power to enter upon public or private property to enforce the provisions of this ordinance, and any person preventing or obstructing them in any manner from entering or going upon public or private property, whether they be the owners or lessees thereof, shall be deemed in violation of this ordinance, and subject to the same penalties stated above, if found guilty by the proper court. If any person removes or damages signs or otherwise defaces signs or paintings in designated fire lanes or no-parking in fire lanes, such person shall also be deemed guilty of violating this ordinance and subject to the same penalties stated hereinabove. 
(Ord. No. 1169, § 1, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 14-56. - Penalty for violating parking restrictions. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter and who shall fail to report within twenty-four (24) hours and pay the penalty prescribed in section 14-53 hereof, shall upon conviction of any part hereof be subject to pay a fine of five dollars ($5.00), the maximum provided by law, as well as court costs and attorney's fees and all other costs necessary to enforce the collection of the five-dollar fine, provided that said court costs and attorney's fees shall not exceed a maximum of fifty dollars ($50.00). This five-dollar penalty shall be collected by civil suit to enforce same if necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1169, § 1, 8-8-95) 
Chapter 15 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Scope. 
(a)  All taxicabs and other motor vehicles transporting passengers for hire on the streets of the city, as herein defined, shall be regulated by the provisions of this article, and the owner, lessee, driver or operator of any such vehicle who violates the provisions hereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided herein, this chapter shall apply to every motor vehicle which transports persons for hire over or upon the streets of the city, regardless of whether said vehicles operate from a stand or headquarters located within or without the limits of the city, and shall include every motor vehicle which comes into the limits of the city from any point and picks up passengers in said city to be transported for hire to a destination, either in or out of said corporate limits. 
(Code 1965, § 22-1) 
Sec. 15-2. - Vehicles exempted. 
    This chapter shall not apply to any motor vehicle operating under a certificate issued by the public service commission of the state or the interstate commerce commission of the U.S., or which is controlled and regulated by either of said commissions; nor to any motor vehicle passing through the city with passengers who have been received as such outside the city limits and are being transported to a destination outside the city limits, provided that such vehicle does not take on, pick up or receive any passengers while inside the corporate limits; nor to any motor vehicle stationed or located seven (7) miles or more beyond the city limits, which transports passengers for hire into the city from a point outside the corporate limits, but does not take on or pick up or receive passengers in the corporate limits. 
(Code 1965, § 22-2) 
Sec. 15-3. - Conditions precedent to operation. 
    No one shall drive a motor vehicle covered by this chapter in the streets of the city until a written permit to drive such vehicle has been obtained from the mayor or the mayor's duly authorized representative. Before such permit can be legally granted it shall be necessary that the required occupational license be paid, the required bond or substitute therefor as provided in section 15-6 hereof, be furnished and the other provisions of this chapter be complied with, and the operator or driver of said vehicle shall fill out and file with the mayor or designated representative, a questionnaire containing such items of information as are considered desirable, and on such form as may be prescribed by the mayor and approved by the governing body. 
(Code 1965, § 22-3) 
Sec. 15-4. - Stand or headquarters required. 
    The owner or lessee of every motor vehicle covered by this chapter must have a stand or headquarters located in the city from which such person operates, whether the transportation involved is wholly or only partly within the city limits. Such stands or headquarters shall not be established upon any street of the city. The owner or lessee of any such vehicle must file with the mayor a written notice giving the location of the regular stand or headquarters from which such person intends to operate. 
(Code 1965, § 22-4) 
Sec. 15-5. - Registration of vehicles; fee; tag; sticker. 
    Every person owning, operating or controlling any motor vehicle coming under the terms of this chapter shall register each of said vehicles with the mayor. Upon the registration of such vehicle, the owner or other interested party will be issued a certificate of registration and a windshield sticker or tag of such design as is approved by the governing authority, which tag shall be attached to the lower right corner of the windshield of the vehicle in such manner that the numbers shown thereon will be discernible both during the day and at night. For such registration and the cost of tag, there shall be a charge of one dollar ($1.00). The registration fee herein provided for shall be due annually and shall be payable on or before the tenth day of January of each year. Said certificate and windshield sticker or tag shall be returned to the mayor or representative when the authority granted thereby is terminated for any reason. 
(Code 1965, § 22-5) 
Sec. 15-6. - Bond or insurance. 
(a)  No person shall carry on the business of operating motor vehicles covered by this chapter unless and until such person shall have first filed with the city clerk an indemnity bond with surety for each such vehicle used and employed in such service, said surety to be a surety company authorized to do business in the state, said bond to have a minimum coverage of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for personal injury to one (1) person, a minimum coverage of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for personal injuries in any one (1) accident and ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) property damage coverage for any one (1) accident, and to contain the stipulation that any persons sustaining injury or damage to person or property as a result of negligence shall have right of action directly against the surety company issuing said bond as fully and to the same extent as if the bond were made and executed directly in favor of the claimant. Said indemnity or surety bond shall be submitted to the city clerk, who, after making a brief record of such bond, as to the amount, number of bond, its expiration date, agency issuing it, and the name of the company, shall approve same if it meets legal requirements, and the information then recorded shall be available to the public. No such motor vehicle shall be allowed to operate under coverage of such bond unless said bond be kept in full force at all times. 
(b)  In lieu of the bond required and described, every person operating any such vehicle in the city shall have the right to procure public liability and property damage insurance in an insurance company or companies authorized to do business in the state, affording protection to anyone damaged by the negligent operation of such vehicle to the extent hereinabove provided. In the event such insurance should be furnished in lieu of bond, the policy for such insurance shall be delivered to the city clerk and shall be approved by the clerk, and a brief record made thereof as hereinabove described. 
(c)  Each such bond or policy shall provide that it may not be cancelled until ten (10) days written notice has been given the city clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 22-6; Ord. No. 1311, § 1 2-9-05) 
Sec. 15-7. - Permit not transferable; persons not eligible for permit. 
    A permit to drive any such vehicle, issued in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, shall be a purely personal privilege and shall not be transferable. Such permit shall not be issued to any of the following: 
(1)  Any person operating a vehicle on which the required license tax has not been paid, or the required bond filed, or the required station or stand established, or where the owner or operator has otherwise failed to comply with the terms of this chapter; 
(2)  A person who has been convicted of being the keeper of a house of ill fame or who is or was directly or indirectly connected therewith or interested therein; or who has been convicted of pandering or any other crime opposed to decency and morality; 
(3)  Any person who is physically handicapped to such an extent that such person's operation of a motor vehicle is dangerous to the life and safety of the public, or who suffers from any defects of sight, hearing or other infirmity which interferes with the safe and proper operation of a motor vehicle on the streets of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 22-7) 
Sec. 15-8. - Suspension, revocation of permits. 
    The mayor may revoke or suspend any permit previously issued for any of the above causes. Such permit may also be revoked or suspended for failure to maintain the bond or other security provided herein, or for using the streets of the city for stations or stands from which to operate, or for failure to comply in any respect with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 22-8) 
Sec. 15-9. - Appeals. 
    The applicant for permit or the holder of a permit which has been suspended or revoked shall be entitled to appeal from the ruling of the mayor to the governing body as a whole, and shall be entitled to be heard and to be represented by counsel of applicant's own choosing at such hearing, provided that applicant gives written notice to the mayor within ten (10) days after said permit has been revoked or suspended of the intention to appeal therefrom. 
(Code 1965, § 22-9) 
Sec. 15-10. - Unauthorized drivers. 
    The owner or person carrying on the business of operating vehicles covered by this chapter shall not permit anyone to drive such vehicle who has not obtained a permit as herein provided. 
(Code 1965, § 22-10) 
Sec. 15-11. - Records. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or lessee of vehicles covered by this chapter to maintain records which will show at all times the name of the person operating the vehicle, the license number and other identification of the vehicle being operated, the hours during which said person operated said vehicle and such further information as may be required under rules established by the mayor for the purpose of providing immediate and ready identification at any time. This provision is considered necessary in the interest of public safety and so as to furnish to the police and other enforcement officers the identity of the driver of such vehicle in cases of accidents, crimes or other instances where such knowledge is necessary or desirable to the proper enforcement of the law. 
(Code 1965, § 22-11) 
Secs. 15-12-15-15. - Reserved. 
Chapter II. - AMBULANCE SERVICES 

Sec. 15-16. - Definitions. 
    Ambulance or private ambulance. Any privately owned vehicle equipped or used for transporting by the use of one (1) or more litters the wounded, injured, sick or dead, including emergency vehicles used for such purpose. The vehicle shall provide space for a driver, two (2) attendants whose qualifications are hereinafter set forth, and a minimum of two (2) litters for patients positioned so that at least one (1) patient can be given intensive life-support during transit. 
    Driver. Any person who drives an ambulance and possesses a current certificate of qualification in multimedia or advance first aid issued by the American Red Cross and, further, that they apply for and be enrolled in a training course designated to qualify them as an emergency medical technician-ambulance, within six (6) months from the date of their employment as a driver, and has successfully completed said course within one (1) year from the date of their employment. 
    Emergency medical technician-Ambulance. Any person who has successfully completed an eighty one (81) hour basic emergency medical technician training course approved by the department of transportation and development and the department of health and human resources, and is currently certified by the State of Louisiana and the National Registry of Emergency Medical Technicians. 
    Emergency medical technician-Intermediate. Any person who has successfully completed an emergency medical technician intermediate training course approved by the department of transportation and development, the department of health and human resources, and the State of Louisiana, and is currently certified by the Louisiana State Board of Medical Examiners and the National Registry of Emergency Medical Technicians. 
    Emergency patient. An individual who is ill, injured or otherwise incapacitated and is at risk of needing medical care during transportation to or from a health care facility. 
    Health officer or designated agency. The person or agency who is duly appointed or recognized by the City of Crowley to implement the standards provided herein as to the required equipment in ambulances. 
    Owner or operator. Any person who owns or controls an ambulance for the purpose of providing both emergency and nonemergency medical care and transportation. 
    Person. Any person, firm, partnership, association, company, or organization of any kind. 
    Registered emergency medical technician-Paramedic. Any person who has successfully completed an emergency medical technician paramedic training course approved by the department of transportation and development, the department of health and human resources, and the State of Louisiana, and is currently certified by the Louisiana State Board of Medical Examiners and the National Registry of Emergency Medical Technicians. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-17. - Permit required by owners or operators. 
(a)  No owner or operator of an ambulance shall permit it to be used or operated upon the streets of the City of Crowley without first obtaining a permit therefor from the clerk of the City of Crowley. 
(b)  The City of Crowley is hereby given authority to promulgate such reasonable rules and regulations as may be necessary to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-18. - Application for permits. 
    Applications for permits shall be made to the clerk of the City of Crowley upon forms prescribed by it and shall include: 
(a)  The name and address of the owner or operator of the ambulance. 
(b)  A description of the ambulance including the make, model, year of manufacture, Louisiana license number for the current year, motor and chassis numbers, and a statement regarding the length of time the vehicle has been in use. 
(c)  The location and description of the place or places from which it is intended to operate. 
(d)  Such other information as the City of Crowley shall find reasonable necessary to make a fair determination of whether the provisions of this article have been complied with. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-19. - Qualifications for permit. 
    In determining whether a permit shall be issued, the City of Crowley shall give weight and due regard among other things to: 
(a)  The probable permanence and quality of the service offered by the applicant, to include among other things, proof of financial responsibility and the establishment and maintenance of a bona fide office within the corporate limits from which the service is offered; and the ability of the applicant to provide both twenty-four hour emergency and nonemergency response. 
(b)  The experience that the applicant has had in rendering services in the parish, the past experience of the applicant in prompt adjustment of claims and in payment of judgments, if any, arising out of the operation of such vehicles. 
(c)  The financial ability of the applicant to respond in damages. 
(d)  That insurance as required by this article has been secured. 
(e)  The character and condition of the vehicle to be used as determined after inspection as required by this article and the ability of the applicant to have available for use and operation in the parish at least three (3) ambulances to be stationed in Acadia Parish, all of which is capable of providing advance life support and to provide a backup system consisting of additional ambulances; and the said ambulances shall meet all of the requirements of the federal specifications for ambulances pursuant to the U.S. Department of Transportation current KKK-A-1822A and appropriate amendments. 
(f)  That applicant has established a dispatch center with both UHF and VHF capabilities able to handle dispatching and coordinating of the aforementioned units with emergency communication capabilities to and from the aforementioned units and the said owner or operator shall possess current licenses necessary for UHF frequencies established by the Federal Communications Commission and commonly referred to as Med 1-10 and with a VHF Hospital Emergency Administrative Radio Frequency of 155.340 megahertz for emergency medical communications between the vehicles and hospitals. 
(g)  That all requirements of this article and all other applicable laws and ordinances have been complied with. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-20. - Insurance required. 
(a)  Before any permit is issued hereunder, the applicant must file with the clerk of the City of Crowley, policies of public liability insurance issued by an insurance company qualified to do business in the State of Louisiana which shall contain the following conditions and stipulations and shall be approved as to form by the district attorney: 
(1)  The term of such insurance policies shall be for a period of not less than one (1) year. 
(2)  The insurance polices shall provide public liability insurance with bodily injury limits of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence (person), medical malpractice liability insurance with limits of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence (person) and property damage coverage with limits of five hundred thousand dollars($500,000.00). Provider must also show evidence of umbrella coverage of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00). 
(3)  Such policies shall by their terms provide that it may not be canceled except after ten (10) days written notice thereof to the Acadia Parish Police Jury. 
(b)  Any owner or operator who fails to secure another policy of liability insurance prior to cancellation of an existing one shall automatically and without notice of hearing suffer suspension of his permit until such time as such insurance policy has been filed with the City of Crowley. 
(c)  Any person who operates an ambulance without having such liability insurance in force shall be guilty of a violation of this article and shall be punished as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-21. - Inspection of ambulances. 
(a)  Before any permit shall be issued hereunder, all of the ambulances listed in the application shall provide verification that it has been inspected by an official Louisiana Motor Vehicle Inspection Station and has a current inspection sticker and shall be certified to be in proper mechanical condition. Each ambulance shall also be inspected by the health officer or the designated agency and shall be certified to be equipped in compliance with standards for ambulance equipment. 
(b)  Said inspections shall be conducted annually as required by state law. 
(c)  Any person who operates an ambulance without having obtained the mechanical inspection certificate required shall be guilty of a violation of this article and shall be punished as hereinafter provided. 
(d)  The owner and/or operator of any ambulance service whose ambulance has a mechanical defect shall be given fifteen (15) days in which to have it repaired. After the expiration of said days, the name, registration and license number of each ambulance remaining uncertified shall be considered unsuitable for operation within the City of Crowley until the following annual inspection date. 
(e)  Each owner or operator shall pay to the City of Crowley a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) annually for each vehicle permitted; said fee to be due on the date of the initial inspection for any given year. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-22. - Driver's license required. 
(a)  No person shall drive an ambulance upon the roads of the city, and no person who owns or controls an ambulance shall permit it to be so driven unless the driver shall have then in force a driver's license issued under the provisions of this article. 
(b)  A list of certified drivers shall be submitted to the secretary of the Acadia Parish Police Jury annually. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-23. - Qualifications for driver's license under the provisions of this article. 
(a)  Person must be at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(b)  Person must have a current motor vehicle chauffeur's license issued by the State of Louisiana. 
(c)  Person must have a current certificate of qualification in multimedia or advance first aid issued by the American Red Cross and, further, that they apply for and be enrolled in a training course designated to qualify them in an emergency medical technician-ambulance, within six (6) months from the date of their employment as a driver, and has successfully completed said course within one (1) year from the date of their employment. 
(d)  Never been convicted anywhere under the laws of this state, or any other state, or of the United States, or other applicable laws of parishes and cities of the offense of murder, aggravated battery, aggravated rape, simple rape, aggravated burglary, simply burglary, aggravated kidnapping, simple kidnapping, armed robbery, simple robbery, pandering, prostitution, soliciting for prostitutes, illegal possible or sale or use of narcotics, contributing to the delinquency of a juvenile, indecent behavior with a juvenile, and has not been convicted two (2) or more times of any traffic offense during the year preceding the filing of the application. 
(e)  Never been convicted of any other felony, or of any misdemeanor involving moral turpitude against the criminal laws of this state or of any other state, or of the United States within five (5) years, and has not served any part of a sentence therefor within five (5) years, before the date of the filing of said application, and they are not presently charged therewith, or with any of the felonies, offenses of misdemeanors set forth in paragraph (d) of this section, or with violating any of the provisions of this article. 
(f)  Not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquor, does not use any narcotic drugs, and is not suffering from any disease or infirmity which might make them an unsafe or unsatisfactory driver. 
(g)  [Be] knowledgeable of traffic laws of the State of Louisiana, familiar with the geography of the city, and is physically able to operate motor vehicles. 
(h)  The owner or operator shall provide a copy of the driver's traffic and police record which shall be attached to the registration and kept on file in the office of the City of Crowley. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-24. - Certification of physician. 
    Each certified driver shall be required to obtain a certificate from a reputable physician certifying that he has examined the applicant within ninety (90) days and in his opinion the applicant is not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquors, does not use any narcotic drugs, and is not suffering from any disease or infirmity which might make them an unsafe or unsatisfactory driver. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-25. - Denial, suspension and revocation. 
(a)  Every owner or operator and driver located under this article shall comply with all parish, state and federal laws. Failure to do so will justify the suspension or revocation of the permit or license. 
(b)  The City of Crowley may deny any applicant's permit or license whenever in the exercise of its reasonable and sound discretion, and after notice and affording the applicant a hearing thereon, it shall determine that said applicant is not a fit and proper person to have such permit or license. The applicant may appeal within ten (10) days from such denial to the City of Crowley for a hearing on said denial for the City of Crowley to determine if such denial is justified. 
(c)  The City of Crowley is hereby given authority to suspend any permit or license issued under this article for failure or refusal to comply with the provisions of this article, such suspension to last for a period of not more than thirty (30) days. The City of Crowley is also given authority to revoke any permit or license for failure to comply with the provisions of this article; however, the permit or license may not be revoked unless the holder has received notice and has had an opportunity to present evidence in their behalf. 
(d)  Whenever a person who shall have been issued a permit or license under this article shall be charged in any court with a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude, or with any felony, or with violation of this article, the City of Crowley is hereby given authority to suspend the permit or license pending final disposition of the charges against them, and to revoke same upon conviction thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-26. - Unlicensed drivers. 
    If any person not licensed under this article is found driving any ambulance, the City of Crowley may immediately take the necessary action to revoke the permit held by the owner or operator. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-27. - Emergency medical technicians (ambulance). 
(a)  No ambulance shall transport an emergency patient in the City of Crowley unless it is an advanced life support ambulance capable of providing advance life support services and whose crew shall consist of at least one (1) nationally registered paramedic and one (1) driver. 
(b)  No person shall be permitted to serve as an emergency medical technician who does not hold a current certificate of registration from the Louisiana State Board of Medical Examiners and the National Registry of Emergency Medical Technicians or a registered nurse with advance cardiac life support certifications (ACLS). 
(c)  Any new employee who does not possess the above noted certificates of qualification hereby required may be temporarily employed, but must obtain said certificates within ninety (90) days after employment. Such employee shall not be permitted to serve upon any ambulance except in company with an emergency medical technician-ambulance who is fully qualified under the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 7-11-2000) 
Sec. 15-28. - Standards for ambulance equipment. 
(a)  Required equipment in each ambulance shall include, at all times when the ambulance is in use as such, equipment adequate in the judgment of the health officer or designated agency, for dressing wounds, splinting fractures, controlling hemorrhages, and providing oxygen. 
(b)  The health officer or designated agency is authorized to promulgate regulations to implement the standards provided herein as to required equipment in ambulances. In determining the adequacy of equipment, the health officer or designated agency shall take into consideration the current list of minimal equipment for ambulances adopted by the American College of Surgeons or its duly authorized Committee of Trauma. Each licensee of an ambulance shall comply with such reasonable regulations hereunder as may be promulgated by the health officer or designated agency and shall maintain in each such ambulance, at all times when it is in the use as such, all such equipment as may be prescribed by the health officer or designated agency hereunder. 
(c)  In addition to any equipment required by the health officer or designated agency, no ambulance shall be operated unless it has the following equipment on board. 
(1)  All such required equipment as listed in the U.S. Department of Transportation current KKK-A-1822A and appropriate amendments. 
(2)  All such required equipment as listed in the current American College of Surgeons bulletin. 
(3)  Extrication equipment shall normally be carried on the ambulance unless a rescue vehicle appropriately equipped and staffed routinely responds to an emergency requiring such equipment. 
(4)  Special emergency radio. In addition to standard radio communication equipment for communication between vehicle and base station, all ambulances shall be equipped with UHF frequencies established by the Federal Communications Commission and commonly referred to as Med 1-10 and a high-bank VHF radio for use on the megahertz (H.E.A.R. Network), for emergency medical communication between the vehicles and hospitals. 
(5)  Oxygen inhalation equipment. Two (2) oxygen supplies, one (1) which is portable and the other installed in the ambulance. 
(6)  Suction equipment for the aspiration of secretion. One (1) suction unit which is portable and one (1) suction unit installed in the ambulance. 
(7)  Airways. Esophageal obturator airway, and oral pharyngeal airway. 
(8)  Wound dressings. Supplies shall be carried for the dressing of open wounds, and for padding and application of splints. 
(9)  Splints for upper and lower extremities. 
(10)  Emergency childbirth kit. 
(11)  Additional medical items required are military antishock trousers (MAST), snake bite kit, disaster bags, intravenous fluids necessary to replace blood loss or as a lifeline for medications. 
(12)  Radio.
